output: Mr President, Mr President, Madam Vice-President, the Commission gives the impression of acting like a distracted pupil who rushes to make up for lost time before handing in their work.
Certainly, the social package exists, but it is incomplete and can only be considered a step towards the Commission addressing social issues.

The Commission President has not taken into account the warning given by citizens in France, the Netherlands and Ireland, which would unfortunately have been the same elsewhere if a popular vote had taken place.
These votes are warnings.
If Europeans want more Europe, it is to build a societal project and not just to adopt even more technical directives.
Regulation of the internal market is certainly necessary, but it is far from being the most important thing.
The 2009 program, like the previous ones, will miss the mark.
Citizens do not expect the Commission to merely supplement, or even simplify, legislation.
They expect the Commission to rise to the task assigned to it by the treaties, to be the locomotive, the idea generator of the Union.
It is not enough for this that its president be wise and silent at attention behind the president of the Council.
We expect the Commission to act as a key player in the discussion on the nature of the societal project we need.
But what is the social project in this program?
The 2009 program does not contain any serious errors, but it is not the program that our fellow citizens need.
Mr President, it will be up to the new college to take responsibility.
I only hope that he will be less deaf to the calls of the peoples than the current one.
Mr President, first of all, a question to the Council.

the guide of the high-level conference on Georgia that had been proposed by the French Presidency and how the current Presidency of the Union intends to defend the territorial integrity of Georgia, while one country recognizes two separatist regions, Abkhazia and South Ossetia.
But it's a shame that Mr. Barroso isn't here because, in his speech, he wasn't convincing, perhaps because he himself isn't convinced by the proposals he has made to us.
I think the financial and economic situation is much more serious than he described it to us.
Even today, I believe that those who follow the Internet can clearly see that the stock exchanges continue to collapse despite the interventions.

For me, it is truly the collapse of the current system, a completely obsolete system, the system that has led to bankruptcy, that has led to a land being totally exploited and suffocated by greenhouse gas emissions, that has led to underdevelopment in the South and that has led to underdevelopment in our cities.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, the current financial crisis clearly demonstrates that when the problem is global, it requires a global response.
And this is true, especially in the field of agriculture or in the food industry.
This is the reason why the World Trade Organization was created, which we agree on, and which is trying to establish global rules.

It turns out that it doesn't work quite as we would like because we are faced with a problem: we need to reconcile two things: the necessary free trade, on which everyone agrees, but the equally necessary protections.
and the protection of national economies or agriculture does not mean protectionism.
To achieve this, the path we have taken for 60 years, since the GATT, is an unbalanced path that goes from reducing customs duties with the goal of eliminating them.
It turns out that, technically, the reduction of customs duties
It is quite difficult, as evidenced by a whole series of mathematical formulas: the South Korean formula, the European formula, or the most well-known formula, the Swiss formula.
It doesn't really work because a product is not unitary.
It is composed of many elements with very different rules of origin, and technically reducing tariffs is not as simple as one might think.
We are therefore in a technical deadlock and are trying politically, through negotiations, to get out of this deadlock.
Or, it turns out that, technologically, a new customs technology has been invented: the technology of customs duties deductible by the exporter on the economy of the importing state.
In concrete terms, this deductible customs duty is converted into a customs credit equal to the amount of customs duty that the exporter has borne in the importing country.
This three-character customs credit is refundable, negotiable, and can be increased.
It is refundable at the time when the exporter goes to buy from the importer, he can deduct the customs duty he has borne.

It is negotiable because, if the exporting company that has borne a hundred in customs duties has nothing to buy from the importer, it negotiates without customs credit on the stock market or in a bank.
It can be increased if we want to help developing countries, the importer, to offer a customs credit amount higher than the amount of customs duty.
Well, with this technique, we create a currency for international trade whose money supply is equal to the amount of existing tariffs.
For example, the European Union would offer 13 billion euros in international currency in the commercial sector.

Mr President, the Russian-Georgian conflict and the financial crisis have provided the European Union with an opportunity to assert itself on the world stage as a full-fledged and first-rate political player.
Thanks to your determination, Mr President of the Council, Europe has managed to unite and find coordinated, effective and rapid responses.
In the face of crises, Europe proves that it exists and demonstrates its added value.
In matters of immigration, for example, the "every man for himself" approach was no longer appropriate.
The adoption by the European Council of the pact on immigration and asylum, initiated by the French presidency, constitutes a considerable step forward.
On the fight against climate change, Europe must set itself concrete objectives and show the way to its global partners.

You have already expressed your opinion on this matter, Mr. President of the Council, but we want this agreement to be as balanced as possible, because it must take into account the economic situation of our countries, which are currently very destabilized.
but also make us question the type of development we will choose for the future.
To meet the challenges that lie ahead, the European Union needs the Lisbon Treaty more than ever.
We understand the concerns of our Irish friends, but the status quo is not an option.
Ireland must propose a solution to us at the European Council in December; many of us are asking for this.
In recent weeks, we have observed with pride that a strong political Europe, united in adversity, determined in the face of its partners, has been listened to on the international stage.
We want this new European mentality to become the norm and to endure.
The Lisbon Treaty is the best solution we have to achieve this.
Madam President, Mr. Minister, I was in Tbilisi when President Sarkozy came to negotiate the peace plan, and of course, I pay tribute to him for having acted quickly and managed to stop the war.
But this war is somewhat our failure. We were timid for fourteen years, we watched the escalation of provocations in the separatist regions in silence.

This war, to be sure, has awakened Europe, placing it before its responsibilities, but the fire continues to smolder in the Caucasus, and we must do everything possible to definitively resolve the frozen conflicts for the security of all of Europe.
I am also aware of the divisions, Mr. Minister, among European countries regarding Georgia's entry into NATO, and personally, I am against it.
I will make a proposal, I will ask the European Union to propose the status of neutrality for these Caucasian countries.
Only a neutral status can ease tensions with Russia and definitively prevent new conflicts in this sub-region.
This status will ensure the security of these young democracies and contribute to our own security.

Mr President, Mr Minister, the last three days have seen the European Development Days, during which there has been much discussion of the food crisis that is severely affecting the poorest countries.
All the interventions emphasized the absolute necessity for developing countries to develop their own agriculture by making optimal use of their land and natural resources.

Incidentally, the effusive praise of those who yesterday and still today call for reducing state intervention and public spending, liberalizing all of Asia, privatizing, and relegating agriculture to the sidelines.
This quasi-prehistoric activity, this about-face in favor of massive public investment in agricultural production and food sovereignty, was both ludicrous and scandalous.
The future of agriculture in developing countries is directly related to the debate we are having today.

Unfortunately, I do not feel that this health check of the CAP, initiated before the peak of the hunger riots and the disastrous market disturbances, takes into account the situation of the peasantry in the South and draws all the necessary conclusions from the serious ecological, social, economic, and financial crises we are experiencing today.

I therefore deeply regret that the strong relationship between farmers in the North and the South is so little addressed, both in the Commission's proposals and in the Parliament's report, and the questioning of the promised one billion euros shows just how far we still have to go.
Mr President, the report we will be voting on tomorrow marks the culmination of a year of work and negotiations dedicated to the future of the Common Agricultural Policy and our farmers.
Indeed, it was on November 20th that Mrs. Fischer Boel came to present her proposals on the health check to us.
Following Lutz Goebbels' progress report, here is Capula Santo's report on the Commission's proposal.
Our two colleagues should be congratulated for their excellent work.
The European Parliament's Committee on Agriculture has managed to remain firm in the face of the Commission's initial proposals, which we considered to be far too liberal.
Madam President, I will remain vigilant with regard to the dairy sector and, in particular, the measures preceding the abandonment of quotas.

I am thinking in particular of mountain milk producers, who should not be the poor relations of this reform, and we must be careful not to leave them behind because they will need more support than others.
I don't want to play the stuntman, but how can one imagine the French dairy industry concentrated within a single region?
I therefore welcome with goodwill the proposal to establish a milk fund and the one to evaluate the increase in milk quotas in 2010 based on market trends.

Mr President, the calculation of the progressive modulation made by the Committee on Agriculture seems fair to me and would allow us to strengthen the development of territories, rural areas, and sustainably preserve biodiversity.
I also welcome the clarification of eco-conditionality, the implementation of which was previously a real headache for farmers.

I also hope that we will maintain the tobacco fund, which allows us to preserve small farms in Europe and a significant workforce in a region where nothing else is viable, and which enables us to avoid imported products.
Finally, Minister, we have greatly appreciated your commitment throughout these negotiations.
You have shown great patience and determination, and you have not counted your time away without fault.
It was a real pleasure to work alongside you.
You have been highly effective with us.
I know that we can count on
Mr President, first of all, thank you for the work done and for the conclusions and guidelines proposed by the CAP health check, Mr Cabulos Santos' report.
Agriculture is indeed an economic sector that cannot respond to simple market signals.
Its activity has impacts, of course, on food self-sufficiency, but also, as is all too often seen, on territories and on employment.
The removal of market instruments would be a serious blow to our agriculture.
Decoupling, for example, poses a real challenge for certain cattle, suckler cow and sheep farming regions, and I was pleased to hear Mrs Fischer Boel address this issue earlier.
Moreover, it is clear that the strict maintenance of historical references would put a huge brake on any possibility of reform.
However, I still believe that the issue of the second pillar of the CAP is an essential one because rural areas need to rely on agricultural activity to develop employment in the countryside.
We must therefore consider this second-foot problem without, of course, amputating the first.
Given that Minister Jouillet is leaving us, I believe that this Parliament should thank him.
He was one of the most assiduous ministers we have ever known.
I wish him good luck.

Madam President, I voted for the Perisch report on the integration of Océane 20 into the single Océane, I must say with a heavy heart, because I believe that this single Océane does not simplify things and does not increase transparency.
it will make life more complicated for winegrowers and the entire wine industry.
Last night, the commissioner tried to reassure us.
I hope that the Commission will keep its word and that, above all, the profession will continue to be adequately represented on the advisory committee, as has been the case since the first WTO.
- He's a real gentleman.
Mr President, Mr Minister, Commissioner, dear colleagues, our group enthusiastically supports the Small Business Act project that the Commission presented to us last June.

Certainly, from the 2000s onwards, initiatives were taken for SMEs, and I am thinking in particular of the excellent work of our colleague Dominique Vlastoo on the SME charter, initiatives that were appreciated but considered insufficient because they too often remained pious hopes.
Today, we must go further.
The severe economic crisis that our countries are experiencing, and the consequences of which are particularly worrying for SMEs, invites us to do so, if there were any need.
In this regard, the Small Business Act represents a new, resolutely proactive approach.
In a few weeks, we will examine Mrs Herzog's report on the Commission's communication, but today, by tabling this oral question, we wanted to question the Council.
Mr. Minister, we have taken note with interest of the conclusions adopted yesterday by the Competitiveness Council and we would like to know if the European Council of December 11 and 12 will

will certainly uphold its conclusions and give a strong impetus to ensure that the major guiding principle of 'think small first' is rapidly transposed into the regulatory framework of the Member States.
We want the Council to commit to the principle of the action plan annexed hereto, accompanied by concrete measures.
In this regard, and in the short time allotted to me, I will emphasize three areas in which we need binding incentives.
Impact assessments, which should be systematic, and regular monitoring, with the European Parliament's oversight of the implementation status of the Small Business Act in the Member States.
access to public procurement
The code of good conduct is not binding. We must be more imaginative and innovative together and propose concrete, tailored measures that genuinely open up these markets to SMEs.
Finally, access to funding, more essential than ever in the current context.
Your proposals are good, Minister, they must also include support for supply.
There is an emergency.
Please assure us of the Council's willingness.

Mr President, Mr Minister, Commissioner, we all know that SMEs are the backbone of the European Union, as they employ more than 70% of the European Union's workforce and account for 99% of European businesses.

But, as has already been said, these millions of small and medium-sized enterprises are now worried and threatened by the financial crisis, because it degrades household purchasing power and confidence, and impacts order books.

It is therefore the cash flow of SMEs that is at risk, and it is therefore necessary to ensure that their activities are supported by guaranteeing that banks provide effective access to the financing necessary for the continuity of their operations.
This is the main issue at stake in the conclusions of the Competitiveness Council on December 1, which Mr. the Minister spoke about, and in the recovery plan approved by European finance ministers.
Making the needs of SMEs a permanent political priority of the Union is essential, and I wanted to commend the Small Business Act for Europe action plan.
It indeed reflects the desire to ensure the effective application of the guiding principle of giving priority to the small ones first, that is, to European SMEs.
However, as the Commissioner said, and as we all say, the Council must truly engage with the other institutions.
European Union, in order for this principle to be effectively implemented, we must go beyond the declaration stage and move on to implementation in all European policies and programs.
However, we can say that this action plan is a real response to the urgency of the situation.
And I wanted, Mr. Minister, to commend the French Presidency of the Union for its proactive approach, which enabled the swift translation of intentions into actions.

Mr President, Madam President-in-Office, Commissioner, I fully support the rapporteur who is defending the position that was ours at first reading, a position that was rejected by the governments of the Member States.
Mr President, it was urgent to bring our legislation on on-call time into line with the case law of the Court of Justice, and this has now been done.
The CERCAS report provides balanced and protective responses for employees.
All on-call time is counted as working time.
The compensatory rest period occurs immediately after the period of service.
It is a matter of common sense to ensure decent working conditions, especially for medical professions.
But the reform of the Working Time Directive also gives us the opportunity to advance our European social law by abolishing the individual opt-out.
The CERCAS report seizes this opportunity and proposes a gradual elimination of any possibility of derogation from the legal maximum working time.
We must face reality.
It is a joke to say that the employee is in a situation of equality with his employer and can refuse what is offered to him.
Dear colleagues, we must clearly show the governments of the member states that the text they wish to impose on us is unacceptable.

In the chorus of praise that will undoubtedly soothe the ears of the French government from tomorrow, it seems to me necessary to focus first and foremost on the employees who will be called upon to work even more without truly having a choice, and this like all those who will be asked to work on Sundays in France.
It is, in fact, clearly to open up this possibility that the French government has changed its stance on the individual opt-out at the Council.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let us listen to the employees and try to respond to their call if we do not want the negative votes in the French, Dutch and Irish referendums to be followed by many others, calling into question a European Union that gives them the feeling that it does not address their daily problems.
Mr President, it has been a very fine French presidency.
There were very few dissenting voices, to be sure.
The twenty-seven overcame their differences to reach a series of exemplary decisions.
On the climate and energy package, Europe is taking a first step, and in this respect, this first step is immense.
It now has the means to assume its environmental responsibility without sacrificing its economy.
It can now take the lead in this area to guide other continents towards sustainable development.
Moreover, Ireland proposes a scenario to break out of its isolation.
Our Irish friends will once again have all the information at their disposal when they vote on the Lisbon Treaty, since practically all the other members will have made their final decision.
The current crises demonstrate that the Union needs the best institutional tools more than ever to be effective.
The European Council has adopted a massive and coordinated economic recovery plan, based on long-term productive investment and targeted support for the most severely affected industrial sectors.
President Sarkozy raised the issue of reducing certain VAT rates, and I fully share his point of view.
Let's hope that the ministers of economy and finance will reach an agreement in March that seemed impossible to the heads of state and government last weekend.
The challenges facing Europeans provide an opportunity for the Union to prove itself to be more united, more responsive, and more concerned with protecting them.
We are grateful to the French Presidency for having instilled this new dynamic.
Like Nicolas Sarkozy, we hope that we won't have to revisit the all-night council meetings that ended at four in the morning to negotiate over three peanuts any time soon.
Over the past six months, Europe has indeed changed its mentality, its scope, its credibility.
We must thank the French Presidency for this, we are well aware that it is not entirely foreign to us.
The situation in Gaza is known to everyone.
what we are discussing here in Parliament is natural.
But we are asking the Security Council to take a stand, the authorities to take a stand, the European Union to take a stand, while we in Parliament are debating and do not want to take a stand.

I believe that, despite everything, given the urgency of the situation in Gaza, it is of utmost importance that this Parliament takes a stand and clearly states what it wants to do to stop the massacres currently taking place in the Middle East.
I find it unacceptable that this Parliament does not have the courage and clarity to vote on a resolution after our debate.
That is why our group is asking for the decision of the Conference of Presidents to be revised and for the debate that we have, that we must have, to be completed.
We need to address the situation in Gaza through a resolution that will demonstrate this Parliament's clear and firm position of a majority to stop the massacres in Gaza.

We want a resolution, we must be aware that we have a political responsibility in the face of what is happening, and this political responsibility cannot simply be a discussion, it must be a resolution that clearly states what we want and what we denounce.
Mr President, Commissioner, more than ever, the proposal for a directive that Parliament is about to vote on evokes in me a very mixed feeling.
It is true that the rapporteur, Mr Klinz, has been working on this for years and has negotiated skilfully, particularly during the trialogue.

It is also true that the directive has achieved a number of significant advances, moving towards better functioning of the internal market and collective management of financial assets, and has been welcomed as such by the European investment fund industry.

That being said, the debates and discussions in the Council and Parliament were never entirely free, since the outcome was known in advance. For some stakeholders, it was essential, at all costs, to introduce the European passport for management companies.
In principle, there is nothing to object to; the passport is quite defensible. However, it is necessary to ensure that the introduction of the passport for management companies
It comes with the necessary guarantees, particularly in terms of fund supervision, as it leads to a separation of functions across borders.
Or, I note with regret that the system put in place is not only complex, but that it is subject to divergent interpretations.
It is likely to quickly encounter practical difficulties that will harm the European export finance industry, particularly in relation to exports to third countries.
I have taken good note that my position is in the minority, but I do not feel uncomfortable.
Under normal circumstances, I would have been tempted to say that only practice will allow us to draw definitive conclusions on this matter and thus determine
Who is right between those who trust in the adaptability of market players and those who adhere to a more cautious approach?
Success is not out of the question, but, on the other hand, nothing guarantees it either.
Or, the very recent news, particularly the Madoff scandal and its implications for the collective management of financial assets industry, is not likely to reassure us.
My skepticism is followed by my concern.
The investment fund industry will not be spared by the financial crisis, we can already see that.
Fundamental reassessments may be necessary in this context of crisis.

That, in this context of profound crisis, we are making choices that dilute the responsibilities of the actors or that presuppose perfect cooperation between regulatory authorities can truly seem like an incongruity.
I tell you, as I see it, this directive is also that of a bygone era, from before the crisis.
It is marked by a certain carelessness.
Indeed, the financial system is going through a lasting and fundamental crisis of confidence, and entire sections of its architecture need to be rethought.

Let us not forget that the primary function of UCITS is to protect investors by diversifying risks and establishing strict rules. By voting for this text as it stands, without really knowing where we are going, we are doing a bit as if nothing had happened.
This autism does not bode well, which is why I will abstain, even though I signed the compromise amendments negotiated with the Council.
And given the circumstances and the improvements made, it seems to me that little weight has been given to the matters of principle that I have just explained.

Mr President, although the regulation on animal reporting has been in force since January 2007, it appears that the Member States are not systematically complying with the requirement to provide annual reports as requested.
Therefore, a comprehensive analysis remains uncertain, as there are many missing elements regarding the means put in place to carry out inspections.
Mr President, as a member of animal welfare associations and a member of the animal rights intergroup, this issue is of particular concern to me.
For decades, associations have been fighting desperately for guidelines to be established in this area, only for them to be introduced in 2007, revealing a certain laxity among the member states.
I would even dare say a certain bad faith, because, after all, we know that the implementation of controls and inspections is absolutely not insurmountable.
We know the slaughterhouses, we know the farms, we know the routes that cattle take, so where is the problem?

I believe it is important, in our era where public opinion is increasingly sensitized, and rightly so, by animal welfare, whether in terms of breeding, slaughtering or transportation conditions, that states respect these sentiments.
Since I have the floor, I would like to add, regarding transport, that it would be essential to consider and take into account, in addition to transport times, the local weather conditions.
Indeed, a several-hour transport journey in the Netherlands in the spring is not comparable to the same journey in the middle of summer in a country like Greece.
Should night transport not be imposed in these latter cases?
Thank you for considering this proposal in the future.

Madam President, I am delighted that it is a British colleague, our colleague Parrish, who has tabled this text, which shows that the Romanian soldiers, two years ago, did well to go to Great Britain and bring amphorae of olive oil and wine.
But then, two consequences will have to be drawn from this.

It is not very reasonable symbolically to place the Food Agency in Helsinki, and it is not reasonable that the European Commission does not backtrack on the following points: first, re-establishing aid for almond trees, and second, stopping...
The attacks on olive trees, particularly in Andalusia and throughout Europe, stop the attacks on bluefin tuna fishermen in the Mediterranean and the attacks on European vineyards with the buyout.
I suggest that our Commissioner, our President, Mr. Barroso, organize a grand banquet in Portugal with sheep's cheese and wine.
Mr. President, we have indeed all campaigned for the closure of Guantanamo and we have all welcomed President Obama's decision to close this prison of shame.
Today, the question of hosting Guantanamo detainees should not be on our minds.
As Europeans who are committed to our values of defending human rights, we must take responsibility, because it is our duty to welcome these former detainees.
As you may have read - and here I am addressing the Council - in the press, some Member States were not very enthusiastic about this welcome.
Here, I would really like to appeal to the Council and, in particular, to the reluctant Member States to agree to receive these detainees on their territory.

And I will tell you, dear colleagues, that the worst thing would be if the beautiful aid sparked by the closure of Guantánamo were to stagnate because we had not been there when Europe was called upon.

This is important because the European animal feed sector is one of the most significant sectors in agriculture, both in terms of production, representing half of the European Union's agricultural production (120 million tonnes), and in terms of turnover, approximately 50 billion euros.
The European Union has five million livestock farmers and sixty million households with pet animals.

In the past, the European Union has had to deal with a number of health crises, which means that today we must be more vigilant about transparency in order to meet the expectations of farmers, but also of consumers.

The provisions outlined in this report have the advantage of representing minimal cost to industries and great benefit to consumers, who are increasingly attentive to the quality of the products they purchase.
The adoption of this report will help to limit risks by ensuring better product quality, better control, better traceability, and greater information for the farmer, and ultimately, for the consumer.
Today, with the increase in international trade, it is more than imperative to strengthen any prevention mechanism to ensure that the food crises we have experienced in the past do not recur.

Mr. President, this report successfully reconciles the right to information, while strictly defining the nutritional elements that must be included on labels, and the right to intellectual property, which is so important for preserving the competitiveness of our industries.

Mr President, I believe that manufacturers should indeed be required to immediately notify the use of any new raw materials in the composition of animal feed, in order to ensure transparency and facilitate control by the competent authorities.
Including an emergency procedure that allows for the addition of a new hazardous substance to the list of prohibited materials seems to me to be absolutely essential.

Similarly, giving the breeder the opportunity to consult the competent national authority or the European Commission in case of doubt about an unfair claim allows for greater variation in systems, protecting the customer while preserving the fairness of commercial transactions.

I therefore wish to lend my full support to this excellent report, because experience shows that regulation on the labelling of animal feed, which prioritises quality, transparency, traceability and control, is the best guarantee for preventing new health crises in Europe.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is certainly not Europe, still less its High Representative for Foreign Policy Javier Solana, former Secretary-General of NATO, who can play the role of mediator between Israel and the Palestinians.
At most, they are called upon to finance the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip, as they are doing today for Kosovo, Lebanon or Afghanistan.
The Americans and Israelis bomb, the Europeans finance the reconstruction.
This is the division of tasks among allies.
Or, it should be the vandals who pay.
Egypt is at the center of peace talks aimed at a prolonged ceasefire with Hamas.

But the challenge is formidable, as the new Israeli government, under pressure from the third man, Lieberman, a leader of the far right that is democratically accepted there, risks seeing its task singularly complicated in these negotiations.
Indeed, Netanyahu, who is presented as the future Prime Minister, has always opposed a truce with Hamas.
Another difficulty is that Mahmoud Abbas's Palestinian Authority has become a kind of international protectorate in the West Bank, whose legitimacy has significantly diminished among the population.
The last element to consider is the expansion of Israeli settlements, which has never stopped since 1967, making the creation of a Palestinian state in the West Bank particularly delicate.
The ball is now in the Israeli camp, but do the hawks on both sides accept this truce of God that both parties are calling for without giving themselves the means to achieve it?
Allow me to add a thought on France's reintegration into NATO's integrated military structure, which will be debated in conjunction with the Vatanen report.
This reintegration will impose severe obligations on France.
In fact, we are rejoining NATO now that the Cold War has been over for 90 years.
Sarkozy seems to have forgotten the fall of the Berlin Wall and Russia's return to the ranks of free nations.
Should the logic of blocs be strengthened at a time when multipolarization and the rise of emerging countries, including in military terms, are on the rise?
Furthermore, France's membership in the integrated structure will oblige it to reinforce its contingent in Afghanistan, even though it already has 3 men on the ground.
What budget will it use to finance this, when its defense budget is set to fall below 2% of GDP and more than 30 regiments are to be abolished?
Paradoxically, we will increase our budget participation to join NATO and reduce our military presence in Africa at the same time.
European defense, dear to President Sarkozy, will therefore be a pillar of the Atlantic Alliance.
One only had to read the Lisbon Treaty and its additional protocols to be convinced of this.
Whether in terms of foreign policy or common security, the European path is a dead end that will only lead to alignment with the Americans and their allies.
It is this logic of erasure that we reject in the name of national sovereignty and independence, relying in particular on our autonomous nuclear deterrent.
Madam President, I congratulate our three rapporteurs on this quite remarkable synthesis of the current state of our common foreign and security policy.

Mr. High Representative, you know better than anyone else that Europe is expected today on the world stage to take the place assigned to it by its economic and demographic power and the richness of its democratic and humanist values.

Forced to acknowledge that, despite the will regularly expressed by more than two-thirds of our European fellow citizens, as you have said, certain progress has been made, I will grant you that, over the past ten years, but forced to acknowledge that this Europe still does not exist.
If recent evidence were needed, its erasure in the solution to the new drama in the Middle East would demonstrate it.
There was, and still is, a need for a European presence in Gaza to play an active role there, both in helping the population survive and in rebuilding the
country and in the fight against arms smuggling, which had turned this territory into a launch site for rockets of all calibers.
Despite the fine words spoken in Charm el-Cheikh and in Jerusalem, nothing has yet been done in this regard.

Mr President, I am reiterating here a question that was already asked during the Lebanese crisis: when can we expect, Mr High Representative, the deployment of a European fleet in the Mediterranean, as we did to combat piracy?
We have the means to do so.
Will we ever have the will?
Mr Commissioner, Mr President, dear colleagues, Parliament's decision to accept the urgency requested by the Council for the settlement of the issue has not been taken.
The committee's handling of this issue was unanimous, both in the Fisheries Committee last week and this morning, right here, in plenary.
We are all indeed aware of the need for the European Union to honour the commitments made in Marrakech last November by the competent international commission, ICCAT.
It is a matter of giving effect to the recommendations adopted by this organization in order to address the persistent phenomenon of overfishing of bluefin tuna in the Atlantic.
the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean and to address the serious danger that arises from this for the future of the species and therefore for fishing itself.
Two of our colleagues, the Committee on Fisheries, Mrs Fraga and Mr Romeva i Rueda, were present in Marrakech and will speak about it during this debate.
For my part, I would like to reiterate the importance that our committee attaches to this issue, which involves the main dimensions of the common fisheries policy, namely management.
on the resource, fleet management, compliance with international, regional and bilateral agreements, technical measures and above all control, I will come back to that in a moment.
This characteristic dossier therefore serves as a test, in our view, of the credibility of this common fisheries policy.
For this reason, it was obviously out of the question for the implementation of the new recovery plan to take place without consulting the European Parliament.
I am therefore pleased that the Commission has finally chosen the only legally and politically acceptable path for implementing the agreement.
recommendations from the CETA, namely a proposal for a formal regulation based on Article 37 of the treaty.

The transposition into Community law of commitments made by the Commission on behalf of the European Union in regional fisheries organisations is indeed not a trivial operation, and we insist that it always takes place under the democratic control of our institution.

In essence, I welcome the various measures proposed, which, although burdensome for our operators, are commensurate with the challenges at hand. I would like to emphasize that the most important measures are as follows.
The most important measures are certainly those that will concern control, since it is true that, without control, no recovery plan can be effective.
So, Mr Commissioner, I thank you for this proposal and I invite you to show the same delicacy.
the determination in the concrete implementation of the plan, once it has been ratified by the Council, that you have shown in concluding a satisfactory agreement at the ICCAT level.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I regret that the Council and the Commission have not yet undertaken to define territorial cohesion in concrete terms.
The French presidency is being tested there, and I would like to commend this initiative.
Our Parliament continues to insist that this objective be applicable from the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty and that its contours be specified as soon as possible.

I hope, following the excellent report by Mr. Van Nistelrooij, that territorial cohesion will become the legal basis ensuring the harmonious development of all territories in the Union and allowing the best possible use of the specific characteristics of each European region.
It is essential to better coordinate community policies in order to maximize the impact of interventions on the ground.
Territorial cohesion is not exclusively intended for regions suffering from permanent handicaps.
However, it must focus on the polycentric development of the European Union as a whole, taking into account the characteristics of each territory while preserving their diversity.
This new concept seems relevant to me for taking into account the outermost regions in order to ensure their sustainable and balanced growth.

In this regard, I would like to thank the rapporteur for incorporating into his compromise amendments my requests concerning the specific challenges faced by the outermost regions in terms of accessibility and competitiveness, which are essential elements of territorial cohesion.
Reading the Commission's recent communication entitled "The ORs: an asset for Europe", it seems to me that it wants to apply the whole
recommendations for improving governance in terms of cohesion, thus making the first illustration, somewhat anticipated, of the implementation of territorial cohesion.

I hope that the Overseas General Assembly, which will soon begin in France, will follow the same approach and take into account the significant territorial impact of European policies in favor of the ORs, whose added value is undeniable.
irrevocable and undisputed.
It's amusing to read the conclusions of the presidency of the last Council.
It resembles the victory communiqué of all the defeated armies.

They laugh about it, even with the repeated assertion that once the crisis ends, the Union will build a stronger economy for the future, or with the reaffirmation of a Lisbon strategy that is in full disarray.
Thus, as they become locked in their glass tower, the Eurocrats, Europhiles, and Euro-optimists of all kinds eventually lose sight of reality.
Everyone knows that the eurozone was the first to enter a recession because it had the lowest growth rate in the world for eight years.
But it is also the one that faces the greatest difficulties in terms of industrial competitiveness and the employment situation.
Above all, it is the one that, through the general disarmament of the natural defenses taken away from the nations, is the least armed to react.
In reality, the only merit of this crisis will be to awaken the peoples lulled by the ease of financial anticipation and by antinational propaganda.
Only the states will have the legitimate instruments necessary for any large-scale action, and to do so, they will have to break free from the constraints of the Union and the euro.

For the French, in any case, it is becoming increasingly clear that there will be no salvation without France, no France without French politics, no French politics without national and popular sovereignty.

Madam President, I believe that, indeed, the issue of the distribution of food products to the most deprived is entirely timely, but I believe that, at its core, the Commission's proposal does not correspond to the problem.
The issue of cofinancing concerns me, and I think it is the question of liberalism that has guided CAP evaluations in recent years, and that is what needs to be questioned.
Riots against hunger and sudden fluctuations in food prices are constant indicators of the limitations of agricultural market liberalization.
This liberalization has always been at the expense of vulnerable populations, vulnerable producers, and vulnerable territories.

I therefore advocate for politics to regain its rightful place and take the lead, both at the European and global levels, and that the strategic domain of agriculture and human nutrition, from both a quantitative and qualitative standpoint, is not subject to the strict laws of the market.
Certainly, there is an urgency, and the Zykerski report responds to this urgency, and I welcome that, but I hope that, in the case of the reflection that is opening up on
For the future of the CAP, it should be remembered that the primary objective is to structurally combat the hunger and poverty we experience in all Member States and worldwide.
Rural areas are available to meet food needs through sufficient and quality production, but will they be given the financial and human resources to fulfill this heavy responsibility?
Mr President, in this period of economic recession, it was important that the European Union continue to demonstrate its solidarity with developing countries.
It is worth recalling that in 2007, the European Community and its Member States together provided 60% of total development aid, making the European Union the world's largest donor.
European development funds help to combat poverty while promoting economic development and democracy.

I am therefore pleased that, for the ACP countries, a budget of 23 billion euros has been allocated for the period 2008 within the framework of the tenth EDF, which is practically double the amount provided for in the ninth EDF.
The Court of Auditors concludes in its report that the accounts of the seventh, eighth and ninth EDFs are, in general, true, legal and regular.
We can only welcome the record levels of contract execution and payments for the implementation of the EDFs.
However, I also note that progress must be continued to strengthen the control and monitoring system, as there is still a significant level of errors affecting certain transactions.
Similarly, there is an all too often high risk in terms of budget support, and in my opinion, these risks should be better assessed.
In this regard, I share the view that budget support should only be granted if the recipient country has the capacity to manage the funds in a transparent, responsible, and effective manner.

Mr President, among the priorities we must work on in the future, I would like to mention the integration of the EDF into the general budget of the Community, as this would enhance the effectiveness and transparency of development aid.

In conclusion, Mr President, I also wanted to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, the representatives of the Court, as well as all the staff of the Commission who have done excellent work on the ground, and I obviously regret the absence of the Council and, in particular, of the Czech Presidency.
Madam President, Parliament and its rapporteur were forced to reject a bad compromise, and they were right to do so.
Our delegation remained faithful to the position adopted by a large majority in the plenary, which called for the eventual elimination of all exceptions to the legal working hours.
But the truth is that Parliament was the only one who wanted to move things forward.
The representatives of the European people had made a decision that went far beyond party lines to put an end to this archaic practice known as the opt-out.
We were the only ones to propose a genuine compromise text, which the Council of Ministers splendidly ignored, as did the Commission, for that matter.
The Council and the Commission have aligned themselves with those who are fiercely opposed to any progress in workers' rights in Europe.
Mr President of the Council, it is clear that you have achieved your goal.
The Court of Justice obliges you to consider all on-call time as working time, so you have not lost anything in that respect.
The opt-out you want still exists in practice, so real estate has prevailed.
More than ever, the deputies elected in June will have to fight to achieve a harmonization of social standards from the top.
Ah! But that's true!

Mr President, this is certainly not on behalf of the LIBE Committee, but presumably on behalf of my group. I would like to take this brief minute to express my extraordinarily positive appreciation of Mrs Pagano's report.
I congratulate you, Madam, on your report.

I believe that, in writing this report, you have developed an extraordinarily precise set of requirements for elements that should be prominently featured, Commissioner, in the Stockholm Programme, which I know the Commission is actively preparing.

Allow me to add to all that has been said, with regard to the importance of judicial training, the importance of evaluation, to emphasize two fundamental elements in terms of mutual trust that are at the basis of what could be mutual recognition tomorrow.
One, the independence of the judiciary.
At present, there are a number of countries in the Union where the independence of the judiciary in relation to political power or other powers has not been established.
This is a scandal and this scandal must stop.
Secondly, procedural guarantees.

Until we are certain that, in a certain number of countries, people who are suspected or accused of having committed certain types of offenses benefit from procedural guarantees similar to those that exist in other countries, it is difficult to widely accept the principle of mutual recognition.
This is a fundamental element and I wanted to introduce it into this debate.
Congratulations to Madame Pagat.
Madam President, we cannot remain silent about the situation in Madagascar, and we will not be the only ones to condemn this situation.
The African Union, the Southern African Development Community, the International Organization of La Francophonie, the Inter-Parliamentary Union, the European Union at the Commission's speech,

In the United States, a large number of countries, including my own and Norway, to mention countries from the European continent, have condemned the coup d'état, because it is necessary to call a spade a spade, which took place in Madagascar.
We cannot remain silent and we demand a return to constitutional legality.
We never ask for a return to the division of shares, with, if necessary, arbitration by the Malagasy people, through a consultation in the form of a presidential election or referendum.
It is up to the assemblies and political leaders of Madagascar to determine the most effective form of consultation.
So, what we are asking with this joint resolution is to add our voice to that of the international community to clearly signal to those who have taken power in a completely arbitrary manner that

in a democratic manner and in a way that, even if disguised as a coup d'état, returns to Madagascar's constitutional legality, which is one of the guarantees of the future development of this large island in the Indian Ocean.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, of course I would like to thank Commissioner Dimas for his presence and his responses, and for the attention he continues to give to all these disasters.
We worked a lot together when President Barroso asked me to prepare a report, which he also cited, on the creation of a European civil protection force.
I presented this report on May 9, 2006.
When I read it again and see all the catastrophes that have occurred, I think it is still relevant.
Madame Zavala, obviously, it's not just Greece.
All countries are affected, and I would add that there are not only natural disasters, but also human disasters caused by humans.
I think of maritime disasters, the Erika and so many others, industrial accidents like Chernobyl.
There are other natural disasters besides fires.
I think about the tsunami.
We can fear a tsunami in the Mediterranean one day, as there was one at the beginning of the 20th century that completely destroyed the city of Messina.

Frankly, Commissioner, my dear colleagues, the tools we are using are not up to the task of dealing with these disasters, which will multiply under the dual effect of global warming and transportation.
That is why I think we need to be more ambitious.
I would like to thank the Commission, Commissioner Dimas, all his teams, and the Directorate-General that operate the civil protection mechanism.
I think we need to go further.
Enhanced cooperation can be envisaged with member countries that wish to participate.
If we are not twenty-seven to form this civil protection force, let's start with twelve or fifteen.
And then you will see that it will concern everyone.
When I list the disasters, I can say that everyone is affected: the floods that hit Germany in 2002, and even the major pandemics and terrorism.
That is why, Commissioner, I would like the Commission to take the initiative to go further, to propose that the Member States go further.
Our Parliament, the Committee on the Environment, and the Committee on Defense and Security will support you in these voluntary initiatives.

Mr President, Commissioner, Members of Parliament, this summer once again, the Mediterranean forest has been ravaged by flames in Marseille, in southern Corsica, but also in Italy, Spain and, on a larger scale, in Greece.
More than 400 hectares of forests and fields were reduced to ashes, causing considerable material debates, irreparable damage to biodiversity, and dramatic loss of human lives.
Alarmed by this repeated assessment year after year and aware of the multiplier effect of global warming on fires,
I call for a European awareness campaign to better coordinate efforts and share resources for fire prevention.
I hope to see the realization of a large-scale Euro-Mediterranean cooperation project to combat forest fires within the framework of the Union for the Mediterranean.
I welcome the existing initiatives, particularly the European Forest Fire Information System, a pilot project.
Nevertheless, I call for a reform of the European Union Solidarity Fund to make it an effective tool for responding to crises and to strengthen the European force.
protection and the Euro Aid device conceived by Michel Barnier as early as 2006 to intervene on the territory of the twenty-seven member countries as well as abroad.

I believe that one of the keys to solving the problem of forest fires lies in the exchange of knowledge and best practices in terms of prevention, and I would like to highlight the pioneering role played by the forest firefighters in my own department.
I can, of course, make this example available to Europe, as it may be useful.
Mr President, Madam President, Commissioner, I will be brief.
I think there are two elements in this debate.
The current issue: how to get out of this crisis?
All measures that both help farmers and include intervention measures are necessary and absolutely necessary.
We need to support them and even consider that they are more important.
This is what we are proposing with a number of colleagues here in Parliament.
Secondly, there is a structurally posed question about the management of the milk market, and this is where there is a divergence with you, Commissioner.
You propose to move towards contractualization.

I'm telling you in advance that, in the long term, if industries and farmers enter into contracts, and given that industries are competitive with each other, this will lead to competition on a European scale.
We need public regulation to regulate a market.
There is no other alternative.
This is where the debate will need to begin after this crisis.
I believe that, in this debate, all opinions and all options must be respected, and I fear that we moved too quickly during the health check to address an issue like quotas.

So far, I say to all those who have spoken, we have managed to maintain dairy production in Europe, ensure an extremely developed dairy industry, and at the same time, ensure a price for consumers that has been quite affordable up to now.
Mr President, a few days after the positive referendum in Ireland, I really feel that we can say that we are more European today than we were before.
I am truly, fully, and serenely delighted by it.
Unfortunately, unfortunately, we are still essentially dependent on the decision of the Constitutional Court, but also on the goodwill of the Czech president.
A clear signal of accountability must be sent to those who hold in their hands the future of this crucial treaty for the Union, for our institutions, and for the 500 million Europeans we represent.
We can no longer be held hostage by a few individuals whose sole goal is to thwart the general European interest.

While it is legitimate for some to not wish to go further in European integration, while it is legitimate to express these reservations, it is also legitimate to allow those who wish to progress to do so.
In general, the ratification processes of European treaties too often take on the appearance of a saga or a pyrrhic victory.
We are doomed to constantly have to push hard to ensure the implementation of a treaty and its institutional reforms.
We will have to learn lessons from this chaotic ratification process and also, of course, from this commitment to negotiate the organization of a second one.
I would like a referendum in Ireland, as if it were normal to make a people who have spoken sovereignly vote again, and as if it were normal for assent to a treaty to be a bargaining chip.
The coherence and institutional balance of the European adventure depend on it.
Ratifying a treaty is a minimum requirement of loyalty and cohesion once a country chooses to join the European Union.
We wanted to send a strong signal to citizens by ratifying the treaty for the European elections in June 2009.
What do you think the citizen thinks today about the Lisbon Treaty and beyond, about our internal coherence and our legitimacy?
Mr President, my speech concerns the deterioration of working conditions in Europe.
Today, nearly half of the world's workers earn less than two dollars a day.
12.3 million people are still subjected to slavery and more than 200 million children are forced to work.
In Europe, the number of working poor is increasing day by day, and the International Labour Organization reports 160 deaths each year due to a lack of prevention.
In this context, I would like to emphasize our responsibility towards all those who are deprived of employment and social rights, who work in undignified conditions.
of these millions of workers who suffer morally and physically, sometimes driven to suicide or victims of cancer or chronic diseases due to their working conditions.
It is time to move beyond the religion of working more, the race for profit, and short-term competition.
The right to decent work and the strengthening of the right to work must be at the top of the Union's priorities in the next ten years.
Madam President, Mr President of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, a challenge, a challenge for humanity, a challenge for future generations.

To raise the stakes, Copenhagen must allow for a comprehensive agreement, a single agreement, as our Committee on the Environment Chair, Joleen Anoui, mentioned earlier. An alliance of all countries, industrialized and emerging, is necessary.

Today, with our debate and the drafting of a resolution by our Parliament, we are once again calling on the European Union to maintain its leadership role in this necessary policy of combating climate change.
Let us remember that we must speak with one voice to maintain our credibility.
Yes, we must reach an agreement in Copenhagen to limit the increase in the average global temperature to a level that does not exceed two degrees above pre-industrial levels.
Yes, we must sign an agreement in Copenhagen to achieve collective reductions in greenhouse gas emissions of 30% by 2020 compared to 1990.
But that will not be enough.
It is not only necessary for developed countries to significantly reduce their emissions, but also for developing countries to contribute to the achievement of the objectives.

Industrialized countries must therefore provide sufficient, sustainable, and predictable financial and technical support to developing countries to encourage them to commit to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions.
Copenhagen must thus enable developing countries to move towards low-carbon models.
Allow me to address two paths that I believe are necessary for our future.
First of all, the global implementation of climate change financing based on the taxation of financial transactions.
Next, it seems necessary to me to implement a border tax adjustment in Europe that would penalize imports of products manufactured without any concern for environmental protection.

This involves contracting and transferring the carbon tax collected at Europe's borders to the countries of the South, which would then be used to finance investments in the equipment necessary to combat global warming.

Mr President, I would like to speak along the same lines as my speech yesterday on the preparation for the Copenhagen Summit, and also following on from yesterday's ECOFIN meeting, which was not a success.
I have addressed the responsibility we have, as an industrialized country, to ensure that developing countries can follow our efforts in combating climate change.
In Copenhagen, we cannot pretend that we all have the same capabilities, otherwise it would mean that we all start from the same point and end up achieving nothing.

So, in order to convince our development partners to join us, we will obviously have to address the issue of the aid that must be granted to them and not wait for the outcome of the Copenhagen summit.
At the next European Council, the twenty-seven must absolutely agree on how the European Union conceives aid to developing countries in the important context of climate change.
As I said yesterday, the Council and the Finance Council have not managed to find a common position on this issue.
Nevertheless, we know that this issue is absolutely central.

The European Commission had already made proposals, and I absolutely want us to take the lead in engaging our partners towards the global solidarity necessary to overcome this problem of climate change.
Mr President, I welcome the efforts of the Swedish Presidency to reach an ambitious agreement in Copenhagen, despite the very strong winds of pessimism blowing over these future negotiations.
For my part, I believe that it is not realistic at this stage to admit that the Copenhagen summit is stillborn or that it will not result in a conclusive agreement to be ratified by all parties.
Let us not give in too quickly to pessimism.
I argue that at this stage, we should not lower our ambitions, either in terms of objectives or deadlines.
We must continue to believe in a comprehensive, ambitious, and binding global political agreement, paving the way for the conclusion of a legal treaty as soon as possible.
It is really too early to talk about the deadline for COP 16 in December 2010.
We must now translate our rhetoric into real political will.
We need to clarify our commitment in terms of financial support and aid to developing countries, particularly in terms of technology transfer.
At this stage, a full and collective commitment from the European Union is essential.
I also note on paper the recent but exemplary initiative taken by Brazil, South Korea, Indonesia, and Norway, among others, which have quantified their ambitions to reduce their polluting emissions.

While we can understand the flexibility demanded by the United States, which is only beginning to take the climate issue into consideration, we will still need to achieve quantified, binding, and ambitious commitments in the short, medium, and long term from other major polluters, such as the United States and China.
Otherwise, we are heading for a climate, political, and moral disaster.
Madam President, we all know and have said how important the Copenhagen negotiations are, but while we all hope for an agreement, we cannot accept an agreement at any price.
If the conditions for an ambitious agreement are not met, I very clearly want the European Union to be able to say no and refuse to sign a watered-down agreement.
The European populations that we represent here are waiting for an agreement, an agreement that will enable us to effectively combat all the climate disruptions that we witness every day around us.

They will not be satisfied with mere announcements, with unfunded declarations of intent, with non-binding objectives on which it will be possible to wipe one's feet once the media spotlight has faded.

In Copenhagen, the states will have to make a commitment. The European Union, the only continent to have seen its CO2 emissions decrease since 1990, the only continent to have planned precise, binding and ambitious commitments for the future, cannot bear the burden of the effort alone.

This is why, if other industrialized and emerging countries do not wish to assume their share of the burden, we will have to draw all the necessary consequences by implementing a tax at our borders to protect our industry from competition from those who choose not to participate in a global agreement.
We Europeans are demanding a little more from our manufacturers every day.
Proof of this is the climate package, which was signed under the French presidency.
Proof of this is the national initiatives that, like the carbon tax praised earlier by Mr. Pargno and which I welcome, are pushing for the establishment of an ecological tax system.

A sector like transportation, which is among the largest emitters of CO2, even though some modes of transport, such as aviation, emit fewer greenhouse gases, is increasingly contributing to the fight against climate change.
Or, it is a sector that has been very strongly affected by the crisis.

If, as I hope, maritime and air transport are included in the Copenhagen negotiations, then let us ensure that what is demanded of European industries is also demanded of those in other industrialized countries.
In Copenhagen, world public opinion will be watching its leadership class closely. Please finish, thank you. Don't let us down, thank you.
Madam President, my dear colleagues, the Copenhagen summit is a historic opportunity to change the course of the planet.
We must reach decisions that are even more binding than those made in Kyoto.
We too must call on our leaders to create an international organization like the WTO, responsible for regulating issues of climate change and the environment, to create a fund
adaptation to climate change, in addition, of course, to public development aid, to create a maritime and aviation carbon tax, as should also be done on financial transactions.
We can clearly see the urgent need for global regulation of the environment, just as there is for financial markets and the Internet.
We have the opportunity to open this step of history through the environment.
Let us do it in the image of our highest human aspirations, otherwise we will appear as leaders with no grasp of reality.

Madam President, Mr President of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, my dear colleagues, with less than two weeks to go until the Copenhagen conference, concerns are growing about the success of the climate change negotiations.
Some people are already saying that it will be a failure.
Major world powers are still reluctant to demonstrate the full ambition that the climate emergency demands of us.

By adopting the motion for a resolution tomorrow on the European Union's strategy ahead of the Copenhagen conference, we, European parliamentarians, must demonstrate that our determination is first and foremost total, and that the conference must result in an agreement that is precise, but above all binding.
Furthermore, the binding nature of the agreement that will be reached must not be called into question or challenged.

We cannot indefinitely postpone decision-making until tomorrow, otherwise it will be too late. Hence the need to create a global environmental organization, which today appears not only necessary but also urgent, since it will be led by the UN to monitor the implementation of the commitments made in Copenhagen.
From Copenhagen onwards, we must be able to expect greater clarity and responsibility from the major world religions.
Mr President, I would like to express my support for the joint initiative by the British socialist government and the French government to return Afghans in an illegal situation to their territories.
In fact, contrary to what some people have said, these individuals had their political asylum applications rejected, and this bilateral initiative must now be extended at the European level.

Migratory pressure is a challenge that must be addressed collectively, and this is the purpose of the pact on immigration and asylum, voted on a few months ago and adopted under the French presidency.
We must now go further by pooling our resources and organizing joint return flights funded by Frontex.

The decision of the twenty-seven to ask the Commission for a study on this subject is a first step and, Commissioner, I hope that the Commission will support this proposal, because the fight against illegal immigration is a demand of public opinion and, in particular, of immigrants in a regular situation.
Mr President, I would like to revisit a recent event: the Swiss vote on the minarets.
Certainly, this vote took place in a state that is not a member of the European Union, but it is evident that it touches on a question that is not foreign to us.
I would like to revisit this event because I also see it as an opportunity to discuss secularism, and we can never talk enough about secularism in this chamber.
It is necessary and urgent that the principle of secularity dominates the organization of our society, and I would like to say some simple things here.
First of all, the opposite principle of secularism is not religiosity, or even less so spirituality.
The principle contrary to secularism is religious communitarianism, which enacts rules and laws superior to civil laws, communitarianism that confines individuals within infra-societal groups.
Our Union, by its history, is multicultural and multiethnic.
It is, and it will be more and more so, and only secularism can allow individuals
Mr President, the CESAR programme, which aims to modernise air traffic management in Europe, is a major project.

How will the Commission prepare for the next phase of redeployment of these arts, and in particular the funding of this program, which is essential for the environment as well as for our scientific and technical influence?
Will the Commission follow the recommendations of the report submitted in 2007, according to which a high-level qualified individual should ensure the political follow-up of this program?
Indeed, it will require overcoming numerous legal, psychological, and technical obstacles by unifying national airspaces and making controllers from different countries work together.
If Europe is not capable of unifying its skies, how will it be able to build a strong political entity?
Mr President, Madam Minister, dear colleagues, the importance of the issue of climate change is no longer in question.

These impacts, whether short-term, medium-term, or long-term, are undeniable, even if today the results of the GESE in a certain national newspaper are making headlines and certainly strengthening the positions of skeptics.
The Copenhagen summit appeared to the world as a unique opportunity for global leaders to bear witness, take action, and correct the effects of the process of climate change.

The European Union was at the forefront of this platform, not only because of the bold legislation we have in place to limit the impact of our activities on the climate, but also because Europe represents a union of countries that can truly make a difference.
Certainly, the outcome of the Copenhagen conference can only leave a sense of dissatisfaction, but I refuse to speak of it as a failure.
The world has agreed on the issue of limiting temperature increase to two degrees, even for the most reluctant countries, such as China.
Brazil has just enacted a law aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions by nearly 39% by 2020, in line with its commitments.
Many others have also shown great ambition in terms of greenhouse gas reduction targets.
So I think of Japan and Norway.
Furthermore, it is also important to highlight the very positive consensus reached on the urgency of a mechanism to reduce emissions from deforestation.
A specific and unanimous text was obtained on the implementation of the IRED Plus mechanism to reduce deforestation and thus enable the natural storage of CO2.
Far from a binding agreement but clearly in line with a political agreement, the outcome of Copenhagen should lead us to question the reasons for such disappointment.
I went to the Copenhagen conference, like many of my colleagues, with the desire to participate, to help, to see a negotiating Europe, a leading Europe in action.
I was very disappointed because Europe clearly did not have the place it deserved in the negotiations, especially when it comes to the European Parliament.
In order to assert itself, Europe must be stronger on this issue.
The meeting of our environment ministers in Seville did not yield results, and our officials appeared uncertain and hesitant, leaving us still divided on our objectives.
I hope that Mrs. Heidegger, armed with her proposals and commitments, will be able to raise the European Union's ambitions when she appears before the Environment Committee.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, to avoid caricatures, of which we have heard a few this morning, I would like to remind you of a few objective facts about Tunisia, a partner country of the European Union.
The social situation has evolved very favorably, with a spectacular increase in average income per capita, and now the vast majority of Tunisians meet the criteria for being part of the middle class.

More than 90% of Tunisians have social coverage, and more than a quarter of Tunisia's budget is devoted to education, making it one of the first countries to achieve the millennium goals for primary education.
Finally, as Mr. Michel reminded us earlier, women's rights are recognized and guaranteed.
At the university, there are more female students than male students, 40 of the professors are women, and a quarter of the deputies, local elected officials, or journalists are women.
Many countries could envy such results.
Mr. President, the acts of fanatical criminals who killed Christians in Egypt cannot be attributed to an entire people and its government.
It would be unfair to hold Egypt and the Egyptians responsible for this abominable massacre, the perpetrators of which will be brought to justice.
Let us not confuse the acts of a criminal with the policy of a country, let us not equate fanatics with an entire population. Finally, by pretending to intervene
Between the Coptic Christians of Egypt and their Muslim compatriots, we are providing arguments to extremists who seek to present Eastern Christians as agents of the West.
I heard you, excuse me, Madam President, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what is happening in Greece, in Portugal, tomorrow in Spain or in Ireland is scandalous.

These same Anglo-Saxon agencies, which complacently rated the fraudulent issuers and traders of toxic assets and saw nothing coming, are now being extremely harsh on the states that came to the rescue of a financial sector that did not deserve it.

The crisis caused by the irresponsibility of the markets and banks, and this massive aid, are directly responsible for the worsening of deficits and public debt that these same markets now claim to be penalizing.
That is the moralization of capitalism proclaimed by Mr. Sarkozy, the European Union, and the G20.

All the bankers have learned from the crisis is that the taxpayer is an inexhaustible source of profit and insurance, as the rumor goes that the extent of this panic comes from a major American bank that benefited from government aid.

of the American state and two hedge funds of the same nationality who want to profit both from the exorbitant interest rates imposed on Greece and from the CDS market, these insurance policies on state loans which are themselves the subject of independent speculation.
It will not be enough to regulate hedge funds, which you are afraid to do, or the derivatives markets, as Mr. Barnier proposes.
There is no need to create a European economic government.
The twenty-seven are in the same boat anyway, and solidarity is not an option.
It is the global free movement of capital that needs to be called into question, otherwise there will be no
Mr. President, there are now fewer than 15 left of the original stock of red wine.
Faced with such figures, the solution seems obvious.
However, we must not forget the jobs affected by the decision we are dealing with today.
It should be noted that CITES does not aim to ban fishing, but only the international trade of this fish, 80% of which is exported to Japan.

By conserving tuna, we are not only protecting a dangerously prized species, but also encouraging the maintenance of a more balanced, sustainable fishing industry, one that is destined for our domestic market and provides jobs.

Mr President, I am in favour of the idea of listing the bluefin tuna in Appendix 1 of CITES and, although I believe that this decision will be positive, the Commission's help in allowing a thorough restructuring of the fishing sector
My question therefore concerns the terms of this support.
France is seeking an 18-month reprieve, accompanied by financial measures for sailors and shipowners affected by a trade ban.
What is the Commission's view on the subject?
Moreover, my concern, like that of many of my colleagues, is about equity.
How can we ensure that ships flying the flags of countries like Tunisia, Libya, or others will enforce the ban on international trade with a rigor comparable to ours?
What will the new control and sanction measures be?

The sustainability policy of our economic activities must be concrete, sometimes even unpopular in certain sectors, but I hope that the Commission and the Council do not lose sight of the necessary adjustments to implement these measures.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as the rapporteur has pointed out, this proposal for a directive is indeed a follow-up to a Parliament vote, and you also mentioned this, Commissioner.
However, my group remains extremely critical of this proposal because it risks backfiring on those we want to support.
By seeking to reduce the burdens on businesses, we risk depriving them of the conditions of transparency and trust that are essential for their management and the dynamism of their activity.
First of all, I believe it is necessary to be clear about the thresholds and what are called micro entities.
These are SMEs with more than ten employees and a turnover of more than one million euros.
Regardless of the Member States, they represent a very large majority of companies.
Admittedly, they may be local and have a limited presence in the Community market, but the need to present accounting rules will not be abolished for them and that
They will have to deal with accounting rules every time they want to deal with a banking institution, with partners, or negotiate with tax, economic, and social institutions.
At that point, accounting rules will be imposed on them and they may have to pay more than for regular accounting in order to meet criteria that they may not fully understand.
I do not see any progress towards the imposition of accounting obligations outside of any common framework within the European Union.
This is not simply a matter of competition, it is quite simply a question of economic integration and Community law and equal treatment for all companies in the European Union.
That being said, of course, simplifying accounting obligations for SMEs is a necessity.
Three initiatives are moving in this direction, including the proposal we are discussing today and the international IF benchmark.
I prefer that it be the revision of the fourth and seventh accounting directives for which the European Commission should soon make proposals to us.
