These proposals were promised to us for 2010, it seems they are being extended, but I do not believe that this extension of the deadline is a sufficient reason for this

to rush into things and do a half-hearted job, because while these three proposals share the same objective, they may not be articulated in the same way, and it seems to me that it would be better, Commissioner,

It is clearer for companies to provide them with a unique and comprehensive response that will allow them to reconcile the goal of simplifying the obligations desired by all and the reality of the lives of small businesses that need them.
The current problem is that the European Commission is dragging its feet in proposing a revision of this directive, and this is detrimental to our thinking.

I therefore call on the European Commission to accelerate the dialogue on the issue of the exemption that is currently dividing both the European institutions and the business community, and to conduct an impact study.

Mr President, Commissioner, and my dear colleagues, as my colleague Elisabeth Morin Chartier and other colleagues have pointed out, on 27 and 28 February, the violent storm Xintia hit several regions in France, causing 53 deaths and enormous material damage.
The storm was of rare intensity, causing devastating floods along the French coastline.
After Madeira, Europe is once again affected.
Brittany, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Cadec, was severely affected.
Three French departments have thus been declared to be in a state of natural disaster: Brittany, Poitou-Charentes, and the Pays de la Loire.
Faced with these disasters, the European Union must demonstrate its responsiveness and express its solidarity.
It is not only through words and resolutions, but also and above all through financial aid that we can support the victims of these disasters.
I therefore call on the European Commission, and my colleague Christophe Bécuy agrees with me, to quickly release the Union's Solidarity Fund to help the affected regions cope with the damage.
This disaster demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier's proposal to create a European civilian intervention force.

Europeans must act together because disasters are multiplying and affecting our European territories, particularly our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as the islands in the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Madam President, I would also like to congratulate our rapporteur Jürg Leichtfried for his text and his spirit of cooperation on this issue, and I particularly support his proposals on the financing of aviation security, since we are talking here about aviation security and not air safety.

Our committee has been fighting for many years to have the principle accepted that the most stringent safety measures must be the responsibility of the Member States, and I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, security is not just a concern for travelers, but for all citizens, and it is the responsibility of states to take measures to combat terrorism.
It is therefore not justified that air passengers alone should be responsible for financing security measures at airports and on board aircraft.
This is especially true in the case of transportation modes such as rail and maritime, where states finance security measures either partially or entirely, depending on the situation.
I therefore believe that we must remain firm in the face of the Council and defend to the end Amendment 32 of the report adopted by our Committee on Transport.
I had another point to address briefly.

While I support the advancements in non-discrimination and transparency that the text will bring, I do not believe that the purpose of this directive is to establish a single, uniform European system of security charges.
While requiring compliance with common rules, Member States must be allowed to retain their current system of levying fees.
Thus, in states like Spain, Italy, or France, fees are voted on by Parliament, and in this case, it must be the appeal authority against the laws that serves as the independent supervisory authority.
And that is the purpose of Amendment 40, which I hope many of you will support when we vote on it.
Mr President, Commissioner, the report I am presenting to Parliament attempts to explain that, in the fight against global warming, agriculture has a place and a role to play.
Nature reminds us this week that volcanoes in particular can have a major impact on human activities and on the climate.
This requires, however, that men and Europe in particular take responsibility for combating what is called global warming.
My report attempts to demonstrate that agriculture can simultaneously continue to reduce its carbon emissions, decrease its fossil fuel consumption, and, on the other hand,
Moncotte has been very actively involved in carbon sequestration, aiming to reduce overall carbon emissions and increase the amount of carbon fixed and sequestered.

This report attempts to demonstrate that in agriculture, we should move away from an approach that is, how to say, compartmentalized, which consists of opening a directive every time a problem arises.
on soils, on water, on pesticides, who knows what else, and to try to approach the agricultural issue with the ambition to deal with it in a comprehensive, systematic way.
In this approach, we should be able to find ways to ensure that agriculture, as I mentioned earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption, but also actively participates in carbon sequestration.
This is particularly the role related to photosynthesis, biomass, and especially what I hold dear, also related to the soil, to the ability of European soils to sequester organic carbon.

I believe that this approach, which I am opening up in this report and which I hope will be followed during the vote that will take place in plenary in Brussels, must enable European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability, ensuring a

ecological transition to this agriculture, which would put it ahead of a number of other continents or other forms of agriculture, in order to ensure that it is capable of being economically efficient, ecologically efficient, and I also think that, from that point on, it will be socially efficient.

This report deals with a specific issue: the fight against global warming and agriculture, but it aims, I hope in any case, to open up other perspectives to fuel the debate on the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
I am addressing the Commission, I will address, and I have done so often, the agricultural committees, and I will also address the various ministers when I have the opportunity.
I think we need to take a turn.
This 2013 CAP must be ambitious.
It must be based on objectives that enable citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy because the Europe of agriculture must ensure both food security and commit to the path of sustainability.
This is, in any case, what I propose in this report and this is what I hope Parliament will follow, by a large majority.

Mr President, I would first like to emphasise that the precautionary principle implemented by most European governments by closing their airspace in a targeted and temporary manner was a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our fellow citizens must take precedence over all other considerations, and under these circumstances, the attitude of certain airlines demanding the immediate and total reopening of airspace after just one or two test flights appears to be, at the very least, indecent.

I believe it was Mr. Henain earlier who spoke about the complementarity of transport modes, particularly with trains, and I will take this opportunity to express how much I regret the air travel paralysis.
This has been exacerbated in some countries, such as France, by the disruption of rail transport due to strikes in these irresponsible and incomprehensible circumstances.
To return to our topic, I would like to commend the Commission's decision to authorize the granting of public aid to airlines affected by the ongoing disruptions.
And it is a sensible decision in a context already marked by crisis, but these aids must be exceptional.

In this regard, I hope that among the criteria chosen for their award will be the exemplary conduct demonstrated by the companies in compensating their customers who are victims of flight cancellations.
Indeed, it is not acceptable that certain companies abuse the force majeure clause in order to escape their obligation to compensate passengers under Regulation 261/2004.
Travelers are victims of the current situation and, if no alternative solution is offered to them, they should not, moreover, bear the financial cost.
In addition, travel agencies are exempt from the obligation to reimburse travelers for unused flights.
And that is not normal either.

Companies, such as travel agencies, have insurance that covers them in exceptional cases, like the one we have been experiencing for the past few days, and therefore it is necessary to ensure that travelers are properly compensated for flights that have been canceled.
Mr President, confusion, chaos, paralysis, cacophony, catastrophe, disaster - the press is not short of words to describe the closure of European airspace and its consequences.
I will not dwell on what has already been said, particularly when people lament the colossal, abyssal financial impact of this crisis, whether direct or indirect.

While I welcome the possibility of considering the allocation of exceptional public aid to the aviation sector, which has already been heavily supported since September 11, 2001, I remain perplexed about the European management of events.

1. Knowing that 750 European passengers were injured, many of whom are still stranded around the world. Knowing that the economic losses are exponential with the passage of time, how can we explain that it took
It takes not one, two, three or four, but five days for European transport ministers to meet by teleconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the creation of differentiated traffic zones.
Secondly, no one disputes the need to apply the precautionary principle as a matter of absolute priority, but today, as traffic is gradually being reauthorized in areas
secured, with unchanged weather conditions, and while the volcano is still active, one has to wonder what additional safety guarantees for passengers we could not have provided sooner, more quickly.

Third, a dynamic action model has been developed, as the evolution of the situation, depending on the weather and the volcano's activity, can change from hour to hour, and it will continue to conduct updated safety assessments of the corridors.
Should these test flights be carried out by civil aviation and airlines?

Finally, if this continues, worsens, or recurs, which is likely, the management model put in place will need to provide for greater coordination among member states and special operational procedures based on real data.

coordination of other means of transport, in exceptional circumstances, but also taking into account the necessary coordination of assistance for the repatriation of the tens of thousands of stranded passengers, who also have a right to information and assistance.
Or, up to now, only isolated and national initiatives have been taken.

Madam President, I would like, in turn, after other speakers, to express my thanks to our colleague Méndez de Vigo, who has done remarkable work under sometimes passionate and always exciting conditions.
The debates within the Committee on Professional Affairs were long, they were equal to the challenge and equal to the intensity of the interest that the countries concerned obviously put into it.

The European Parliament, whose major issue concerns them first and foremost in a completely legitimate way, is the composition of our assembly and the procedures for designating the members of our assembly.
Once again, the rapporteur has managed to bring together sometimes differing opinions and contributions and synthesize, I would say, in an extremely balanced text, the opinions and views.
I wanted to thank him for that.

I believe that the recommendations of these two reports, both the one concerning the convening of the IGC and the one concerning the transitional measures for the composition of our assembly, are imbued with realism, pragmatism, and efficiency.
This is, I believe, what, overall, on other subjects as well, our fellow citizens expect from Europe.
Mr President, Mr Dalli, Commissioner, this draft report, as presented just now by Mr Peterle, follows the Commission's lines with great strength.
This is the directive of the European Commission's communication and is also inspired by the European Parliament's resolution of April 10, 2008 on the fight against cancer in our European Union.

Allow me to support the objectives of the European partnership envisaged by the European Commission to combat cancer more effectively, whether it is the importance of prevention and early screening, the development of a new cancer prevention model, and, above all, the reduction of inequalities within the Member States.
I share the concerns and worries expressed in the European Commission's communication and the draft report.
I would like to commend the work done by Mr. Peterle, the rapporteur, in drafting this report and the compromise proposals put forward to incorporate the various amendments.

As the shadow rapporteur for the Socialist and Democrat group, I wanted, among other things, to emphasize the following issues: first, the increase in annual cancer deaths caused by exposure to carcinogens in the workplace, but also the importance of better access.

information on medicines for cancer patients, but also the implementation of the REACH regulation and the regular update of substances of very high concern, which include carcinogenic substances, support for initiatives aimed at preventing the import of goods

containing carcinogenic chemicals and to strengthen the control of chemical substances within the European Union and, finally, the development of guidelines for a common definition of disability that could include people suffering from chronic illnesses or cancer.
These are the questions we have been considering while providing our support for this draft report.
Madam President, the oil rig leak in the Gulf of Mexico is a true ecological and economic disaster.
It would appear that irregularities have been found in the granting of forest permits by the US Department of the Interior.
This would be an unforgivable oversight, the consequences of which are incalculable and do not concern only the United States of America.

When one considers that hundreds of offshore drilling permits are granted by states around the world, if these permits were granted with the same laxity, it would pose serious problems for the entire world.
elected representatives from outermost European regions and OCTs composed entirely of islands, almost entirely of islands, nearly 130
In total, spread across three continents, I must express my deep concern here for our islands in relation to offshore oil exploration projects.
This is why it is imperative that the European Union, which must set an example, reviews the safety and prevention measures on its own offshore oil platforms with the utmost rigor.
Moreover, accidental or operational oil spills at sea, not necessarily due to Europe, are estimated at several tens of thousands of tons each year.

Would it not be appropriate for the European Union to take initiatives so that offshore platforms now fall under the jurisdiction of an undisputed international scientific authority, which should be established in the form of an international authority?

After Copenhagen and in preparation for Cancun, the European Union would be honoured to initiate a genuine global governance framework for the research, protection and exploitation of deep-sea resources.
The continuity of the Barcelona Process, the Union for the Mediterranean, is an opportunity for the development of our relations with the countries of the east and south of the Mediterranean basin.
As the excellent report by Vincent Peillon points out, we cannot ignore either the potential of this region or the dangers it poses.
However, having the lucidity to recognize this since the bombing of Gaza and with the continued colonization of Palestinian territories, the Union for the Mediterranean is at an impasse.
The political aspect is blocked.
We are not even certain that the summit scheduled for next June in Barcelona will actually take place.
I would not be surprised if we learned in the coming hours or days that it has been postponed, adjourned.
We should not give up, but the European Union must take greater responsibility in seeking a political solution.
We cannot leave the United States with a monopoly on the political management of the crisis in this region, which is our own, by merely contributing to its development.
The development and stability of the Mediterranean are crucial for our security and growth, and for this reason, the Union for the Mediterranean remains the best instrument at our disposal.
Mr President, Commissioner, this is an extremely important issue concerning consumer protection.
A recent survey indicates that the food safety situation has deteriorated over the past ten years in the eyes of Europeans, and that one in three consumers remains wary of product quality.
Updating, simplifying and clarifying the labeling of food products in the European Union is therefore an obligation for better consumer protection.
Allow me to address two points.
Regarding the color code, we are in favor of this color code if it is accompanied by a reference to the nutritional values expressed as a percentage.
Then, I am opposed to mandatory nutritional labeling for wines and spirits.
We want a specific regulation for wine and spirits to be developed within the next three years, instead of the five years proposed by the European Commission.
That is what I wanted to point out, Mr President, Commissioner.
Mr President, Madam High Representative, this attack on civilian ships by Israeli commandos obviously requires an impartial and credible investigation.
But what credibility could we grant to a commission that would be both judge and party?
This attack occurred in international waters, and therefore concerns the international community, and is of particular interest to Europe, which borders the Mediterranean.
Europe should make its voice heard more and become more involved in the search for a political solution based on two states, each with Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe is making considerable financial efforts to contribute to the development of Palestinian territories, but unfortunately, it is too absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of this Palestinian state.
The financial and budgetary goodwill we are showing is not enough.
We must also express a political will and take the necessary steps to make ourselves heard.
The brutal murder of the Mavi Marmara by the Israeli army has sparked emotions and condemnations.
I would like to express my emotion at the nine civilian victims of the assault, and my condemnation because this boarding in international waters constitutes a violation of international law.

In doing so, the government of Israel is penalizing its people because, in the end, we see, with the strengthening of the extremes, the ultimate goal of security in the region moving a little further away.
Yes, more than ever, the government of Israel must abandon the policy of force.
However, I would like to point out that the extensive media coverage of the Mavi Marmara flotilla, orchestrated from Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation seems essential to shed light on the assault, as well as on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
And I hope that the government of Israel will agree that this investigation includes substantial international participation in order to finally find the paths of justice in this region.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, I welcome the new momentum generated by the launch of the Partnership for Modernization and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, if it served only this purpose, would at least have the merit of highlighting how Russia is an indispensable geopolitical partner for the European Union.
I also welcome the positive comments on cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
A few remarks, however.

While the Union's demands are always emphasized, the interests or positions of its partner seem systematically undervalued or disregarded, whether it is in the field of energy or in the way it can analyze the Eastern partnership and the Atlanticist aspirations of its closest neighbors.

I also note that the firmness displayed by most Member States and the Union in their speeches, the virulence of their condemnations of human rights violations, seem to be reserved exclusively for Russia.

The language is more police-like, diplomacy is more filtered, as if we were talking about China, for example, with its systematic violations of the rule of law, even in relation to the workers at this global factory, in light of European minimum social requirements, while our French or European workers are unemployed.

Allow me to remind you of the adage of Adagusta, father Augusta, towards the summits by the narrow paths, for this is how I view the efforts of today's Russia, freed from the criminal Marxist poison that, for so many decades, bled and imprisoned this country.
The current Russian Federation has managed to lift the spirits of an entire nation despite the significant difficulties and challenges that still lie ahead.

So, a little modesty, gentlemen Europeanists, especially when the European superstate fails to achieve any of its lofty goals despite increasingly costly measures and the progressive domination of the states of Western Europe and Central and Eastern Europe.
I cannot help but point out that this Assembly showed more leniency towards the more communist Soviet Union than towards Russia.

It is, moreover, often the same people who, yesterday, were advocating for the unilateral disarmament of the West and for Mr. Gorbachev's participation in the common home, who today are experiencing the most virtuous indignation and the greatest modesty towards the Union-Russia partnership.

In this regard, I must inform you, if you are not already aware, of new historical facts that will emerge as a result of the gradual translation of the secret Soviet archives that a brave Mr. Pavel Stroilov managed to obtain, archives that have already revealed and will continue to reveal many interesting details.

It was an unpleasant surprise for the cacique of the single thought regarding the reality of the end of the Cold War, which was really, Mr. Gorbachev, and the perfidy of today's Euro-enthusiastic powers, who were then eager to make certain Soviet projects possible.
At the risk of repeating myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for European states, and our relations must be strengthened for the benefit of all parties.

This country is much closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interests, and common risks than certain states that you are nevertheless preparing to admit to the European Union.
Mr President of the Council, it is often said that necessity makes law.
Faced with the crisis, one thing is clear, no, I should say, one necessity has become inevitable: the need to innovate, to be creative.

In this regard, I welcome the step taken by the Council, a step that I hope will eventually be a giant leap towards true economic governance, because let us not be mistaken, the mere coordination of economic policies will remain insufficient.
Could we achieve a genuine fiscal federation, not forced by circumstances, but because we ourselves decided to do so?
Let us return to the Council's decisions, which I am nonetheless pleased about.
Strengthening the preventive arm of the Stability and Growth Pact is a good thing, but there can be no real budgetary discipline without sanctions for those who violate it.
They have been strengthened, but not yet specified, which is a shame.

Otherwise, I will express my satisfaction, among other things, with the decisions made, such as the famous competitiveness evaluation dashboard, because that is what it is about: getting back to competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
Let us also welcome the project to establish a bank tax, the acceptance of a tax on financial transactions, and the acceleration of financial regulatory reform.
Mr President of the Council, all these decisions and guidelines seemed, a few months ago, or even a few weeks ago, unrealistic, illusory, or even truly hypothetical.
You are right, it is true, it is a profound cultural change on the scale of European small steps policy.
But that being said, it is now imperative that in October, the states implement these guidelines in a very concrete manner.

It will now depend on the Council whether the step taken is a historic giant leap or merely a pious hope, something that we will all bitterly regret and, in particular, a majority, the citizens, will have to endure on a daily basis.

Mr President, we have already discussed this at the Conference of Presidents. Many groups are divided on this Gallo report and it is clear that Parliament, all the groups, still need to discuss it because there are contradictory points that the groups have not been able to resolve.
That is why we are asking to postpone the debate and the vote on the Gallo report, that is to say until September, 2 September, and we will have to see what the Conference of Presidents decides.
So, it's a very simple thing.
Since the fruit is not ripe, let's give it the summer to ripen and discuss it in September.

Madam President, I must admit that I find it difficult to keep up with my colleagues who so love to flex their muscles and claim a monopoly on our legitimacy vis-à-vis the other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their posture is often derisory.
But when the members of this house, through hard work and conviction, assert a reasoned position, when
We are defending what appears to be a general European interest in the face of rigid states; the situation has completely changed.
In this debate on European supervision, Parliament has played this role.
Regarding the European Systemic Risk Board, for which I am my group's shadow rapporteur, I have defended, like the rapporteur, Mrs Goulard, an ambitious approach.
I have advocated for mechanisms that ensure a certain level of efficiency and I have emphasized the preeminence of the European Central Bank.
Why?
Because the European Central Bank is indeed the only Community institution in this group and because it has demonstrated its seriousness.
Out of Christian charity, I choose to withhold the names of all the institutions and all those great figures who suddenly disappeared during the storm.
We can consider ourselves fortunate to have had at least one captain on board at the height of the crisis.
I will therefore be reassured to see macro-prudential supervision backed by a strong Community institution tomorrow, while micro-prudential supervision will inevitably remain fragmented.
Having been troubled, the European Systemic Risk Board must get to work as quickly as possible.
The future will show whether adjustments will be necessary, but it is essential to start on a sound basis, as systemic risks affect the entire European and global banking sector.
Mr President, the final agreement reached on the recast of the industrial emissions directives is more than acceptable and I welcome the compromise work that has been done.

This final package incorporates the key taxation points that I defended with several of my colleagues on the Environment Committee, aiming to make this text an ambitious yet realistic piece of legislation.
First, maintaining a certain flexibility for companies and competent authorities in granting exemptions.
Next, I would like to commend the new version of the ESN, which has been so controversial and is now limited to certain sectors, making it seem much more feasible.

It is also important to note that the agreement reached allows for better alignment with the ETS directive and definitively removes from the text of the new directive the irrelevant idea of creating a market for SO2 and NOX quotas.
A few caveats not to be forgotten, however, and more particularly the provisions concerning the ground.
Since the SOL directive is still pending, this important issue will unfortunately only be addressed by the Member States that have their own legislation.
Tomorrow, Parliament must adopt the elements of the agreement reached at the end of the trilogues.

A tremendous amount of work has been done from all sides to avoid sending this text back to conciliation, a text that, I must remind you, is of crucial importance both for the industry and for European environmental policy.
Madam President, each day brings a new set of information that shows us the extent of the ecological disaster caused in the Gulf of Mexico by the rupture of the offshore platform.
But let's not forget that other disasters of this kind are taking place elsewhere.
I am thinking in particular about what is happening today and has been happening for a long time in Nigeria.
That is why, in addition to the moratorium on new drilling, I believe there is a need to promote stricter rules for the management of platforms, not only European rules but also international rules.
As for the European Union, I believe it is necessary for it to equip itself preventively to combat this disaster, and I think it is obvious
I also believe that all of this argues, as Mrs. Damanaki said, for a firm and decisive choice in favor of clean and renewable energies.
The European Union should set an example in this regard.

Mr President, Commissioner, reopening negotiations with Mercosur at a time when the European Union is preparing to redefine its agricultural policy reveals a dangerous lack of coherence on the part of the Commission.
Europe already imports 500 tons of beef.
A new opening of our market would be to the detriment of farmers in disadvantaged European areas, without any guarantee of compliance with health and social standards.
We cannot accept it.
Europe buys 38 million tons of soybeans and cattle feed.
These imports from Brazil and Argentina monopolize more than 19 million hectares.
They are concentrated in the hands of three companies: Cargill, ADM, and Bunge.
Between 2001 and 2004, soy destroyed more than 1.2 million hectares of tropical and equatorial forests.
This was one of the primary causes of the increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the loss of biodiversity.
The European Parliament has decided to produce a report on the reconquest of autonomy in plant proteins for cattle feed.
Environmentally friendly agriculture and the fight against climate change dictate this choice.
These efforts will be reduced to nothing by this draft bilateral agreement.
Once again, the European Commission is selling out its agriculture and its farmers in order to obtain random counter-services for service companies.
These concessions will not serve the farming families of Mercosur, but the interests of agro-industrial groups.
To be convinced of this, one need only read the report of the Tyson group, an American company and a heavyweight in the international meat market.
which announced that it had invested in Brazil to, and I quote from its report, use this country as an export platform for Europe.
Other companies, such as Doo, had already anticipated this approach by acquiring the Brazilian group Frango Soul in 1998.
Many poultry farmers, particularly in Brittany, had suffered as a result of this operation.
Europe, without wanting to pursue its policy of relocation, is amplifying its attacks.
against the peasants, we must stop
Mr President, many colleagues are concerned about the consequences for European agriculture that could result from the reopening of negotiations on an association agreement with Mercosur.
My group and I share these concerns.

Indeed, it is to be feared, and as a Member of Parliament for an outermost region, I have experience of the banana agreements. It is therefore to be feared that an agreement with Mercosur will deal a severe blow to many European agricultural sectors.
This is why an impact study is absolutely necessary.
There is also a fear that this agreement will further shift Mercosur agriculture towards a productivist model, at the expense of small farms that exist in these countries.
A balance must therefore be found so that this agreement does not transform the Latin American and European continents into superpowers anchored essentially in the dogma of mercantilism.
Mr. President, I would simply like to say that perhaps we have not done a good job with our agenda today.
If we allow free trade agreements to enter the territory of Europe, with products that do not respect our social or environmental standards, the reform of the CAP will be for nothing.
To be very clear, we cannot continue to live in a state of hypocrisy where, on the one hand, we impose environmental constraints related to health traceability and safety.
on one hand, we tell our farmers that we need to protect consumers, and on the other hand, we allow products that can freely enter our continent without adhering to these standards.
The question that underlies the negotiations with Mercosur is precisely this one.

The way things were initiated, regardless of what we are told about the fact that Parliament was very well informed and that things took place with the utmost transparency and clarity, does not lead us to have a positive assessment of a negotiation that is taking place while, in parallel, negotiations at the WTO are continuing.
For the sake of consistency, consumer protection and the defence of our farmers, I do not believe we should continue down this path.
Madam President, I would also like to commend the work done by the rapporteur, José Bové, and the Commissioner, as well as the speech by Mr Deß, who spoke before me, on the objectives of this report.

I think it is very important that we keep in mind that, in the debate we are having, we need to address a problem related to price volatility in agriculture and, above all, to the fact that when prices
When prices increase, they are very quickly passed on to the distribution level, but when prices decrease at the production level, there is no impact on consumers.
There is indeed a problem with the organization of the sector, there is indeed a problem with the distribution of what is called added value within the sector.

I believe that José Bové's report offers, on several points, perspectives that need to be highlighted, and here I am really addressing the Commission to try to get out of this fundamentally negative spiral.
The first, of course, is the organization of the sector and the balance of power within the sector.
What are the proposals we are making to enable producers, once united and organized, to have more influence within the sector for negotiation purposes?
This is the issue you raised, Commissioner, regarding inter-branch organizations, but it is also a question about the contractual framework that will be put in place.
I argue, and it is stated in the report, that this contractual basis has a European framework.
We cannot let each country deal with this problem on its own.
There needs to be a European framework.
It must be flexible, but it must exist.
It is a proposal, an inseparable line of thought for me.
Secondly, of course, there is the issue of price transparency.
And in this regard, I am in favor of setting up this observatory, which is absolutely necessary so that we can inform consumers about price trends.
There, I support the proposals that are being made and I hope, as Mr. Desch said, that there will be a majority for

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to take this opportunity today to welcome this debate, which once again highlights the need for the Union to appreciate and enhance its regional diversity.
In these years of negotiation for the new 2014 framework programmes, it seems important to me to highlight the adjustments that specific regions must benefit from.
Issues of territorial continuity and cohesion must be at the heart of our concerns.
But the development of mountainous, island or sparsely populated areas requires more than a set of derogating measures.
We need a horizontal approach.
We must establish instruments capable of making all areas of Community action coexist in synergy in order to enhance their added value.
Moreover, as a representative of the outermost regions, I am eagerly awaiting the Union's new strategy for the ORs that the Commission services have promised us for early 2011.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, first of all, I agree with my colleague's position on the Council's absence from this Parliament meeting.
I find that a bit flippant on the part of the Council, I must say that too.
As the next summit approaches on October 6, China and the European Union must absolutely and resolutely try to move forward together on the issue of climate change.
Last year at this time, we were already busy in this very chamber, urging Europe to do everything possible to reach an ambitious and binding agreement in Copenhagen.
We have seen that the result did not live up to our hopes and ambitions.
So, a year later, the concerns are the same, if not even much more acute.

In order to be able to compel or convince our partners today, we must demonstrate that our determination is absolutely intact, show, for example, that we are providing the means to honor our commitments to the countries of the South.
For this reason, the implementation of innovative financing mechanisms, and I heard President Sarkozy's speech at the UN yesterday, becomes a necessary necessity.
For example, the introduction of a carbon tax at our borders is not to be ruled out.

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that are not going far enough in their climate commitments, much more of a threat in the end and a means of protecting our jobs and businesses, especially to better address the post-crisis period.

Madam President, for me, the need to revalue family leave is not up for debate. Raising the minimum threshold for maternity leave is a step forward, a benefit, and we should not be entirely demagogic in comparing the economic impact to the qualitative benefits that are difficult to quantify.

But the problem is essentially twofold: the economic context, which is true, but not sufficient to leave millions of families stranded for decades; the legal shortcomings of the report, because the text contains several types of family leave whose legal bases are not compatible.
Let's take adoption leave, which is mentioned in the text in the same way as maternity and paternity leave.
I personally appreciate, as an adoptive mother and for all those I represent, the desire to grant equivalent rights to those of biological mothers.
I am actually the additional addendum that Mrs. Morin mentioned, to be added to the Estrela report.

Mr. President, if the goal is indeed to strengthen the health and rights of women, of all women in the labor market, adoptive women who have become mothers on the same footing as others are entitled to the same rights and protections at work.
These are mothers like any others, fully entitled to adopt a child, whether they are over or under twelve months old. Please note that there is no discrimination, as stated in the text.
Regarding adoption, therefore, I regret that the text was not thoroughly enough examined.
It was not even supported by the Ramboll impact study.
This is all rather poorly executed, which is clearly a weak point.

Nevertheless, despite these reservations, I will support Mrs. Estrela's report because, beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better assume their parenthood in a society of the

He is increasingly resigned to the education of his children, but moreover, it is our duty to ensure that no one has to choose between sacrificing their children for their job or sacrificing their job for their children.
Finally, we do not sit on the Council, but in Parliament. If we, the directly elected representatives, are not ambitious, tell me who will be.
Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Council, I would like to speak and not revisit the debate as it has unfolded so far.

We discussed a 2011 budget with the constraints we are aware of, namely those of a deep crisis that Europe is going through, with public deficits at the national level, which can lead to two hypotheses.
Do these national public deficits constrain the European deficit, or should these deficits at the national level give a new direction and a new impetus at the European level?
That is the question.
I ask you, Commissioner, especially to try to remember, when discussing a budget review, when we start talking about the budget outlook for the period after 2013, not to
It cannot remain totally absorbed by the context of the crisis, unless it wants to tell me and all the citizens of Europe that, indeed, Europe will remain in crisis for a long time.
Our whole problem is indeed to manage the crisis and reduce our deficits and debt, but it is also to prepare for the exit from the crisis.
This is where the budgetary question arises.

We will only be able to emerge from the crisis, as Joseph Daul said right away, if the European budget, because it is European, is capable of giving us the means to regain what we lack today: growth, job creation, innovation, and research.

That is the issue, and it is in this light that we must discuss the budget, rather than doing what we do all too often, which is constantly incorporating the issue of the crisis, the issue of deficits. And in this regard, the Council is excellent.

I noted that in Douville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even preemptively announced a reform of the treaties without even having discussed anything with Mr. Van Rompuy to sanction all the states that would not respect budgetary discipline tomorrow.

This is where we stand with the Council today, while Parliament is asking the Commission for one thing above all: to decide to move forward with the European project, and this is happening through the budget.
You have noted a number of things on which we fully agree.
More flexibility is needed.
Obviously, we need to find a way to have a much more flexible budget together, because it is a necessity, it is Europe's responsiveness that is at stake.
It is also, of course, a matter of setting priorities and organizing the efficiency of the European budget.
We will all agree on this, all agree, it is a necessity.
But what we need to be clear about, Commissioner, is that we need a timetable, that we set common objectives together. It can't just be words, commitments, and promises.

These are, incidentally, very interesting texts and I agree with them almost 100%, but now we need to get down to specifics, particularly on an essential issue that we keep circling around: own resources.

How do we ensure that we have our own resources tomorrow for Europe, not for Europe itself, but for all European citizens, and how do we find a way together to return to a path of growth and an even stronger path for Europe?
It is up to you, Commissioner.
Mr President, I would like to focus my remarks on the preparation for the next G20 summits.

Everything has been said by the previous speakers about European economic governance, about the need to strengthen European economic governance, to strengthen the Stability and Growth Pact and to better involve the European Parliament and, of course, the national parliaments in the process.
I would like to briefly mention two challenges that our nations and the G20 members face, and which, in my opinion, must be addressed in the context of the upcoming G20 meetings.
the challenge of the currency war and that of the volatility of raw material prices.
I believe that on these two issues, which are genuine threats to global growth and which cause very significant imbalances on our planet, the Union must act.

The European Commission is managing to organize itself, to establish common positions, and to give itself the means to speak with a single voice at the upcoming G20 summits in Seoul and those that will follow, as well as on the global stage in general.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to start by congratulating our colleague Diogo Feio on the quality of the report and on the ambitious proposal it contains.
This also demonstrates that the European Parliament is taking its rightful place in a debate that is crucial for the future of Europe, and we can only welcome this.
Moreover, the Greek crisis has revealed the dysfunctions that undermine the economic governance of the European Union.
I take note of Mr Feio's proposal to establish a permanent mechanism for financial stability.
We must also address the problem at its root.
To achieve this, I believe that the solution also lies in strengthening the Stability and Growth Pact, particularly the sanctions.
This is essential if we want a sustainable improvement in the budgetary situation of the states, which is not always popular.
It's restrictive, but we have no choice.

Mr. President, I believe that the report clearly demonstrates the challenges posed by the marine environment in terms of fishing, aquaculture, transportation, tourism, energy, mineral and biological wealth, and research combined with climate change.
This is a considerable development potential that must be secured, protected, and sustainably enhanced, because the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also rightly notes that the European Union is the world's leading maritime power and that its outermost regions offer it the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.
In view of this situation, it is therefore up to the European Union to implement an ambitious policy, a major maritime policy.
If it is not the world's leading maritime power that does it, who will do it instead?
But it must be noted that the resolution does not go very far down this path.
One cannot claim to occupy a leadership position in global politics with 50 million euros.
Finally, while the outermost regions have a recognized strategic position, as they are present in all oceans, it would have been possible to reduce them.
It was wise to give them a major role in a major ocean strategy, which, unfortunately, was not included in the report, and I regret that, Mr. President.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to revisit the anti-counterfeiting agreement currently being negotiated, particularly with the United States.
This agreement also raises questions in the United States, particularly among officials at the United States Patent Office.
In addition, 75 American law professors have just sent a letter to President Obama.
They believe that ACTA, a mere executive agreement, would be contrary to the American Constitution.
As the European Parliament is preparing, as you know, to adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, it still raises great concerns and is far from being unanimously accepted.
I believe it would be useful for our fellow citizens to receive a very clear response from our American counterparts on two points: Can ACTA be ratified by the United States?
In their eyes, is ACTA a binding or voluntary agreement?
Indeed, an anti-counterfeiting agreement from which China, India, and Brazil are already absent, and which is not implemented by the United States, would lose much of its credibility.
Thank you.

Mr President, throughout this difficult birth of the Alternative Investment Fund Directive, I have consistently advocated for the principle of equal treatment between fund managers, whether they are from the European Union or not.
This principle sounds like an obvious truth, but this truth has encountered countless difficulties.
The result presented to us today is satisfactory.
I thank the negotiators and especially our rapporteur, Mr. Gozes, who, after this particularly painful birth for him, deserves a substantial maternity leave.
Above all, I would like to emphasize that the issue of how to treat third countries must still be considered in two ways, whether one is inside or outside the European Union.
Thanks, in particular, to the European Parliament, all funds that will be sold in the European Union will indeed be subject to comparable regulation.
One can therefore more or less speak of a level playing field.

Nevertheless, during the transitional period, non-European entities will benefit from the national investment regime, while EU funds and managers will be subject to the directive, which is generally stricter.
The situation is different in markets outside the European Union, where European funds and their managers will remain subject to the directive, which is not the case for third-country funds.
It would then be much more difficult to sell European products in the rest of the world because they will be less flexible and more expensive.
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was, to some extent, inevitable.

Regarding custodians, it's also worth noting that we will make the exercise more demanding, particularly due to the new responsibilities they will have to manage, and their increased costs are expected to lead to substantial changes in the profession.

Mr. President, I am not saying this to show my opposition, but to indicate that this new regulation is not trivial; its implementation, which is necessary, will also involve difficulties that we must be aware of.

Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, especially at the beginning of the 21st century, patients need appropriate information in order to be fully involved in their care pathway, to know where to seek care, to decide on the best treatment in agreement with healthcare professionals, and to follow the prescribed treatment to the letter.
Today, patients demand independent, comparative information tailored to their individual needs.
Unfortunately, the proposals for revising the directive submitted by the European Commission did not adequately address the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals opened the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical companies, which we see as nonsensical in terms of responding to the actual needs of patients.
This operation is of no interest to either the citizens or the Member States.
It meant, on the contrary, more bureaucracy, increased expenses, and putting patients at risk.
It is for these reasons that we initially submitted a proposal to reject these texts, thereby asking the Commission to revise its draft.
This approach, also adopted by my colleague Carl Schilter from the Green group, enabled our rapporteur, Mr Feischner, whom I commend, to make a significant revision of the Commission's proposals.

In parallel, we had tabled around sixty amendments aimed at further protecting the health of our citizens and facilitating patients' access to independent, comparative information tailored to each individual's needs.

The adoption of these amendments in the Environment Committee has placed greater emphasis on patients' rights to information, rather than making the provision of information an option for the pharmaceutical industry.
In light of the compromise amendments achieved, we have decided to withdraw our motion to reject the texts, as the substance of the text has evolved in a positive direction over the past few months.
The draft report, as amended, has managed to counterbalance the initial proposals of the European Commission.

However, we will continue to refuse to allow health professionals to be used as tools to distribute brochures and information provided by pharmaceutical companies to their patients, without any control from health authorities.
Similarly, we will oppose the authorization of industrial information campaigns, particularly regarding vaccination.
Information cannot come freely from pharmaceutical companies.

Experience shows that we must be very vigilant and, moreover, and I conclude, what happened with the mediator drugs shows just how vigilant we must be and ensure that this balance, as we have sought with this draft report,

Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, the Union and realism will be put to the test, at least I hope so, during tomorrow's vote on our resolution on this sixteenth Conference of the Parties on climate change.

I hope that our commissioner in charge will be able to achieve the pragmatic objectives that we will need to reach collectively, but also defend the sine qua non conditions set by Europe that are associated with them.
In these negotiations, we must also not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of fairness of our fellow citizens and our industries.
It is the world that must combat climate change, not Europe alone.
Thus, recognizing the importance of intellectual property that is inadequately protected will be essential.
Green technologies should benefit the greatest number of people, but we must not, for all that, squander our present and future knowledge, even for this indispensable fight against climate change.

Similarly, requesting common methods for calculating emissions, as well as the verification and publication of data so that all emitting industries are subject to the same scale, seems to be a most legitimate request and not a negotiating tool.
Finally, more controversially, and as my colleague mentioned earlier, the shortcomings of the current Clean Development Mechanism system will also need to be addressed.
Dear colleagues, we are all well aware, albeit with regret, that the real negotiating power does not lie with the European Parliament.

But the willingness of many European deputies, including myself, to work and participate in a positive outcome of this conference must be encouraged and not neglected, as we have experienced in recent days.
If Europe wants to be strong in international dialogues, the same must apply to all these legislators.
Madam President, the European Union often presents the economic partnership agreements as an opportunity for African countries.
She is therefore desperate to see these agreements signed as soon as possible.
But the question that concerns us is why these countries are not rushing to sign agreements that would be so favorable to them.
Clearly, opinions differ on the quality of these agreements, and as long as these differing opinions persist, the ACP countries will be reluctant to sign them.
Would it not be appropriate to go further in dialogue and understanding by listening to the concerns and expectations of ACP countries?
They want to talk about development strategy, while Europe often responds by opening up markets.
This is the kind of listening that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly must impose on itself.
I believe that other European institutions should follow the same approach if we want to build a genuine strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Mr. President, Christians are undoubtedly one of the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by certain extremist groups as, and I quote, legitimate targets, and the goal is their outright departure from this region, a region that saw the birth of Christianity and in which their historical presence is necessary for a certain balance.
The events at Baghdad Cathedral are merely the culmination of a situation that we have been passively observing for far too long.
The European Union, as a global player and trading partner of many countries in this region, must strongly express its indignation at the situation.
Discrimination, in any form, cannot be tolerated.
Democracy will only be victorious in this region when the most fundamental human rights, such as religious freedom, are respected.
My dear colleagues, we are all concerned by the serious crisis currently prevailing in Côte d'Ivoire.

It is evident that the decision of the Constitutional Council of this country to challenge, in violation of the electoral code, the results of the elections officially proclaimed by the independent electoral commission is unanimously condemned by the international community.
The European Union, the UN, the African Union, the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, the COAS and soon certainly the European Parliament are calling for respect for the official proclamation
the election results and the installation of the new president of the Republic, as recognized by the independent electoral commission, which, I would remind you, is a body validated by the UN.
All the political groups in the European Parliament have expressed their agreement on these essential points in a joint statement.

They also called for an end to any escalation of tensions in the country that could lead to civil war, which would be a human, social, and economic disaster for Côte d'Ivoire, and which must obviously be avoided at all costs.

Madam President, I would like to take my turn in thanking our four rapporteurs who have done an outstanding job and have added significant value from the European Parliament to the text initially proposed by the Commission.
The citizens' initiative that we in the EPP are preparing to vote for with enthusiasm is a major step forward in the Lisbon Treaty.
Let us make no mistake, this instrument can truly change the European political landscape, provided it is used with both responsibility and boldness, I repeat, responsibility and boldness.
It can help bring European citizens directly into the European political debate.

It can help to foster a European public opinion, that is to say, men and women who are citizens of Europe, who debate together, who take a stand together, and who come together on truly European issues.
But let's not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let us urge our member states to take the necessary implementing measures quickly, let us not disappoint our fellow citizens, this is about strengthening European democracy.
Mr President, I would like, in turn, like several of our colleagues, to address the issue of the persecution of Christians throughout the world, particularly Eastern Christians.
No one needs to remind us of the horrific acts recently perpetrated.
I would like to solemnly remind everyone that defending Christians in the East, as well as everywhere else in the world, advocating for religious freedom, the diversity of religions...

This belief is about advocating for freedom, democracy, and human rights, which are core values of the European project and which are, of course, universal values, at least that is what we are all convinced of here.
It is truly time now, beyond indignation, emotion, and solemn condemnations, of course, it is truly time now to turn words into actions.
I therefore urgently call on the European Union authorities, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, as well as all our leaders, the foreign ministers.
Implement precise measures, establish a concrete action plan to make the respect of religious diversity and the fight against all forms of religious persecution a priority.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam High Representative, we all agree that the situation in the Sahel region has significantly deteriorated.
Allowing a lawless zone to develop on Europe's doorstep is a danger that we must combat firmly and without delay.
Extremist groups are multiplying and threatening the lives of civilians.
For my part, I deplore the loss of life and the taking of hostages and am concerned for the European nationals on the ground.
Until now, Morocco has been a bulwark against all kinds of trafficking coming from the Sahel.
Or, nowadays, drug, arms, and human traffickers bypass Morocco by going through Mauritania towards the Canary Islands in the direction of the European Union.
It seems to me that it is the responsibility of the European Union to take action to help these states put an end to these threats.
Europe's security is at stake on our territory, but also in its immediate neighborhood.
It is time for us to act and I call on the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to help restore security in the Sahel.
That has been said, but I join in the expressions of sympathy and support that have already been made towards the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples.
It represents a symbol of hope for all defenders of freedom.
A thought also for the victims.

I would now like to say that the European Union, which, as has been mentioned, has been noted for its lack of reaction, must indeed stand by the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples to help them successfully open their countries up to reform and establish democracy.

The European Union has decided to support the Tunisian leaders in order to initiate a peaceful transition, prepare for the organization of the upcoming elections, to gain freedom and enable the Tunisian people to find prosperity through development and social peace, an economy that will allow young people to find employment.

In conclusion, I would say that the Union for the Mediterranean faces a significant challenge because the Jasmine Revolution has triggered a wave of change across all the states of the Maghreb, the Near East, and the Middle East.
It must implement a strong strategy towards these countries.
But beware, faced with this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for the legitimate aspirations of peoples, and stability.
Commissioner, my colleagues have pointed this out repeatedly.
At a time when Europe is considering a common strategy for its supply of raw materials, and particularly rare earths, we cannot overlook the immense potential of intelligently valorizing our waste.

Strengthening European standards to improve the functioning of collection systems, addressing the problem of leakage or illegal export of said waste, and increasing our collection targets, must also be at the heart of this legislation.
Let us not forget the main actor in the success or failure of this regulation, the consumer.
Empowering citizens is crucial if we want to implement effective legislation.
To achieve this, my dear Carl Heinz, the eco-contribution, among other systems, has proven to be a most relevant tool.

Producers of electrical and electronic equipment must, of course, become more involved in the collection and recycling system, but citizens cannot be absolved of responsibility for the waste they produce.
Our citizens must be active participants, not passive observers, in European environmental policy.

Madam President, Mr President, Commissioner, I would first like to share the comment that Mrs McGuinness just made about the fact that there is an essential link between the food issue and the agricultural issue.
The issue that concerns us is the increase in food prices, with the consequences this can have for a number of populations around the world, but also in Europe.
I would first like to try to share an observation.

The trend of increasing prices for agricultural products and raw materials is, for me, a long-term trend that will continue for three essential reasons: the demographic evolution of the world and the increase
The second element is that we have entered, with global warming, a period of problematic climate risks, whether it be drought or flooding. The third point is that the world is also developing.
As new emerging countries emerge, consumption levels are rising.
The tension in agricultural markets and agricultural raw materials is a significant trend.
It is exacerbated by price volatility, and price volatility is a consequence of the financialization of the global economy.
This is the issue that must also be addressed if we want to resolve the agricultural and food issues.

To achieve this, what the Commissioner says is important: there are two elements—yes, we need transparency about stocks, but we also need a public stock policy in Europe and stock management on a global scale, particularly at the UN level.

Second point, there must be regulation of financial markets and financial speculation, particularly by refusing to allow speculative volume to have no connection with the physical quantities that are traded on the markets.
We cannot accept that, on the food issue, speculators come to speculate without taking into account the consequences this can have, since it is about the food of the world and humanity. I conclude.
Because this leads to two major consequences: we need a strong European policy and we strategically reaffirm Europe's commitment to being a global food and agricultural player.

Secondly, we need to change our development policy to ensure that, on a global scale, and Europe is a player, we invest again in agriculture, because we will need all forms of agriculture to feed the world.
Madam President, Commissioner, as in 2008, the price of agricultural raw materials is soaring on the global markets.
We are only 3 from the 2008 level.
The decline in production in certain traditional exporting areas due to climate change, the diversion of grain to agrofuel production, and speculation
The financial banks that have accidentally had a bullish effect are responsible for this situation, as shown by reports from the IMF, the French authorities, and as the Commission also states.
The consequences of this new food crisis are severely affecting the 1.2 billion people worldwide who live on less than $1 a day.
Since October, an additional 44 million people have joined those living below the poverty line.
Two days before the G20 meeting, what is Europe waiting for to take similar measures to those voted on in the United States?
Since January 13, 2011, the US administration has required the limitation and transparency of positions taken by financial funds in agricultural commodity markets.
This is the first step in countering the appetites of speculators.
The impact is also dramatic for European breeders.
They are no longer able to feed their animals.
Hundreds of farms are going bankrupt.
Five years ago, wheat was worth 100 euros per tonne, today it is trading at nearly 300 euros.
The situation has therefore completely changed.
The Commission demands that farmers adapt to market signals; it would be wise for it to follow its own advice today.
Faced with this crisis, the European Union cannot wait until 2014 to find solutions.
We must address the crisis, and I propose three concrete actions.
First, the creation of stocks in grain-producing countries to make them available to farmers at subsidized prices immediately.
Secondly, the indexation of meat prices paid to farmers to the evolution of the price of animal feed.
Thirdly, for 2011, a mechanism to transfer a portion of the aid intended for cereal support to animal production. Thank you.
Mr President, are we in Europe ready to face a pandemic?
The answer is yes, but there's a catch.
The 2009 flu outbreak in Chania showed us that each Member State reacted on its own, without much coherence or even solidarity.

As the shadow rapporteur on this issue, I believe it was necessary to make these observations, but above all to go further, to be constructive and concrete for our citizens who, it must be said and this is what seems to me most damaging, have probably lost some confidence in public health messages.

Mrs. Rivasi's report, which will be voted on tomorrow, takes into consideration these fundamental priorities, which include, among other things, the systematic strengthening of cooperation between member states, better coordination with the
European health institutions, clarification of the roles of European health risk management structures, an evaluation of vaccination and communication strategies implemented in the Member States.
It is therefore a good report, I congratulate the rapporteur, but of course it must not remain a dead letter.
It is the responsibility of our member states, which retain the majority of the relevant powers, so it is a genuine responsibility to be taken towards our citizens.
Mr President, it is my turn to express my profound emotion following the cowardly assassination of Mr Bati, the Pakistani minister responsible for Christian minorities, on 2 March.
This terrorist assassination follows many others of courageous, tolerant Pakistanis who love human rights and are defenders of human and women's rights, I must say.

Once again, we urge the Pakistani government to shed full light on this cowardly assassination and to effectively, truly effectively, ensure the protection of those threatened by fanatical religious extremists.
I am thinking, of course, first and foremost, but not exclusively, of Mrs. Sherry Rehmann.
I also wanted, once again, to strongly urge all the relevant institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations aimed at
I would like to prepare future cooperation agreements, including the cooperation agreement between the Union and Pakistan, with a clause on respect for religious freedom and human rights.
Mr President, for your information, with the crisis and the explosion of the real estate bubble and credit, the Irish state had to intervene to support the banks.
Ireland's public deficit, the cumulative budget balance of central, local and particularly social security administrations, was estimated at 32% of gross domestic product in 2010.

If the Irish government, which can hardly refinance itself on the markets, wishes to access loans from the mechanism and the European Financial Stability Fund, it will have to meet obligations for social and fiscal changes, whereas these areas fall under subsidiarity.
In our view, this is not contradictory.
As a doctor, I would say that in the case of fever, it is useless to prescribe antipyretics blindly without trying to treat the cause.
If these funds are allocated, it is up to this state to clean up its finances in order to cover its excessive deficit and correct its previous mistakes.
This austerity plan is expected to improve the GDP by 10% over the next four years.

Just as a private individual, without interfering in their private life and management, will make their personal loan conditional on a guarantee of solvency, the European Union can lend to Ireland on the basis of consolidated solvency.
Without interfering in his private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, a salary increase or to borrow elsewhere.

Thus, while respecting subsidiarity, the European Union, based on a memorandum established with the IMF, considers that this solvency requires a reduction in the minimum legal wage and an adjustment of pensions, without exempting itself from fiscal measures.
It is up to Ireland to decide whether or not to implement these measures.

This is not about opening the door to European Union interference in areas of subsidiarity, which could, for example, dangerously impose a European minimum wage level, but about protecting the stability of the eurozone through a process of mutual guarantee.

It is of course important to help Ireland, as well as other countries in difficulty, which also protects us, but not at any price, especially not at the price of having a state that is unable to repay its debts in the long term, thereby weakening its citizens and those of the entire European Union.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano last April, as many of us have said earlier, provided a painful illustration of the fragmentation and inefficiency of European airspace.
And each one of us in this chamber has been directly affected.
Five million of our fellow citizens found themselves stranded without any real alternative transport solution.
A year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still pending.

A first crisis exercise, as you mentioned, Commissioner, related to volcanic ash is indeed planned for April 13 and 14, under the coordination of Eurocontrol, ICAO, and IATA, but it is essential that EASA takes on real leadership for the coordination of safety measures at the European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the VACs in London and Toulouse must be refined using more modern technological means.
However, as we saw last April, this data can be contradictory and can lead each Member State to make decisions about closing their airspace, motivated less by information than by emotion.
In this context, the role of EASA is essential in providing a harmonized interpretation of this data, as well as ensuring the centralization and proper dissemination of information.
Beyond VAC information, EASA must establish a mechanism for collecting available data by closely involving Member States, airlines, and their pilots.
This centralization of information and coordination of all stakeholders will prevent the chaos and inconsistencies we witnessed last year.
I therefore expect the Commission, together with the ESA, to quickly present concrete proposals that will fully integrate into the implementation of the Single European Sky.
Madam President, dear colleagues, this text is important.
This is not a revolution, so we cannot say that everything was bad before and everything is perfect now.
But nonetheless, it presents a number of major advances at this provisional stage of our work.

In my opinion, the main issues relate to better regulation of distance selling, particularly on the Internet, and this is the subject of Chapter 3, because we need to strengthen consumer rights in this area.
E-commerce is very useful, it broadens the consumer's choice, allows them to get the lowest prices, and also enables small and medium-sized enterprises and artisans to find new outlets.
To make progress in this area, it had to be done in a truly European way, that is to say, on a few very targeted points, implementing a complete harmonization of everyone's rights and duties.
In practical terms, an Italian customer buying from a Belgian or German site needed to know that they would now benefit from the same rights and the same protection.
This is what this directive will make possible.
This means that the withdrawal period will be extended to fourteen days throughout the Union.
This means that he will immediately know the total amount he will have to pay, without the fear of a nasty surprise later on.
This means that, thanks to the double-click, he will correctly check his order.
Of course, all of this will disrupt certain habits.
In many states, there are subtleties in national law that everyone is convinced are fundamental, while sometimes one cannot even find a trace of them in neighboring countries.
But living together in Europe means learning to modify these habits a little in the service of the community and general interest.
Let's be clear, this text still needs to be improved, and we will have to do so in the coming weeks, with the Council and with the Commission.
I appreciated the recent openings made in this regard.
But we have already done substantial work thanks to our rapporteur, Andreas Schwab, whom I warmly thank.
But the real fruit of this work is above all the fact that the amendments will be voted on tomorrow by all the political groups.
Consumer confidence in the EU's internal market is very fragile.
This political unanimity was necessary to preserve it and to hope to strengthen it.
At point 7, after the first paragraph, a first indent should be added to guarantee respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular personal freedom.
Freedom of speech and assembly, and the right to peacefully demonstrate, listen to and consider the legitimate demands of protesters, and ensure their safety.
Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner, the open skies agreement between Europe and the United States is a step forward, but it is only one step, a step that places Europe before a dilemma.
The Transport Committee and the Commission itself have pointed this out.
Either we accept an agreement that disadvantages European companies, or we suspend the agreement and risk losing the benefits gained since 2008.
Let me draw a parallel with the licensing of private and professional pilots, a text that will be discussed before the summer, because pilots, including myself, are faced with a dilemma.
The European Aviation Safety Agency, wishing to harmonize licenses across European territory, will do so at the expense of 90 general aviation pilots.
directly concerned, some holding only one American license, and to the detriment, and this is important, of companies and jobs linked to this activity.
Mr. President, I wish to draw your attention to this project which has no security basis.
There are 31 times fewer accidents among American license holders.

The objectives of the basic regulatory text 216 make it possible to provide for the recognition and equivalence of licenses, for which there is no point in waiting for hypothetical agreements that were postponed in 2014.
So, I propose a very open sky agreement and even invite you to accompany me when I come to Parliament, flying myself to demonstrate that an American pilot's license is perfectly safe.
Madam President, at this stage of our debate, I will inevitably be led to repeat or support certain things that have been said previously.
But I also wanted to say that, like several of my colleagues, the problems we are facing, which the entire European Union is currently facing, cannot be solved by any single Member State alone.
No Member State should be left alone to face the challenges that arise, which, in my opinion, once again, are challenges for the entire European Union.
This is why I am calling for the European Union's ability to organize and respond in a common, united manner.
I believe that the time has truly come now to lay the foundations for a genuine European immigration and asylum policy.
More than a year ago, a European pact on asylum and immigration was adopted.
The time has now come, I think, to put it into very concrete terms.
We have indeed listened, Madam Commissioner, we have heard a number of recommendations she was making.
I wanted to come back to this and strongly endorse some of these proposals.
Yes, we must strengthen the resources of the Frontex agency at all costs.

Therefore, it is necessary to strengthen the human resources, material resources, and financial resources of the Frontex agency, and to enable it to provide more substantial support for the Hermes and Poseidon operations.

Yes, additional financial resources are needed, especially for those Member States that are, I would say, in the front line, in the first instance, facing the increased migratory flow that we are experiencing today.
This will be the financial expression of our solidarity.
Yes, we need to establish closer cooperative relations with the states on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, support them, of course, help them, and find the right tools.
I believe the Commissioner mentioned that she went to Tunisia to discuss mobility partnerships.
Yes, these instruments must be strengthened in a spirit of responsibility, in a spirit of solidarity, but also in a precise and concrete spirit.
