Mr President, Commissioner, you are no doubt aware that the most intense discussions we have had here regarding your communication concern the place of public services, services of general interest, in the single market, and their legislative translation.
We have reached a compromise formulation that invites you to go beyond your proposal 25, and we ask you to go beyond a mere
communication that does not meet the expectations and needs of the actors, users, and all stakeholders of public services, and that does not meet the objectives that you otherwise set.
The European Union must convey a clear and unambiguous message on public services.
To do this, we need to create a positive legal framework, regulation or directive.
The Lisbon Treaty provides us with the legal basis for this.
It is up to you to translate them into legislative proposals now.
I believe that Parliament is ready to follow you down this path.
Mr President, first of all, congratulations to all the rapporteurs for their enormous work on this discharge, and I also welcome the Council's presence for this debate.
The seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg is a matter of European identity and is not just a matter of economics.

I am speaking about this today in this chamber on the occasion of the debate on the 2009 discharge, because the symbol of Franco-German reconciliation is being treated by some members of the Committee on Budgetary Control as a godsend, a mere means of making savings.
I am also interested in the issue of Parliament's expenditure.
In this regard, I propose that we hold the group weeks in Strasbourg rather than in Brussels, which would allow us to make better use of our Parliament headquarters in Strasbourg.
Since we want to save money, I propose other things, for example, to eliminate the Friday afternoon off for our colleagues, as well as the elimination of the afternoon off for journalists.
Europe is attractive enough that one is not obliged to give journalists a perdium.

Let us not hide behind the budgetary argument to appropriate an important issue that goes beyond budgetary control, even though I commend the important work of Ville, our rapporteur, on this discharge.
Finally, since we are talking about savings, I also want to see a moralization and a cleaning up of the compensation system for groups of sponsored visitors.

I don't find it very moral and it gives a very bad image of our institution that the group leader is reimbursed in cash, in specie, on the day of the visit, without any work, no control of what the group has spent.
Sometimes, the allocated amount exceeds the actual expenses, I must inform you.

It would be logical for groups to send a quote in advance to the visits department, for them to receive an account from Parliament detailing the expenses, and for payment to be made into a bank account, with the balance paid upon presentation of invoices that have actually been paid, with a ceiling, of course. Thank you.
Madam President, I am addressing the Commission, my colleagues, and I welcome the presence of the Council.
The question that arises today stems from the management of the Schengen area in 2011.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the 1980s; on the contrary, it is a space that has continually expanded in recent years and now includes twenty-five states, three of which are not members of the European Union.
Like all European policies, Schengen cooperation must therefore adapt to the reality it now covers, which is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.

This is the context in which the proposals of the Italian and French governments and the pragmatic and necessary responses provided today by the Commission in its communication on immigration should be read.
Mutual trust between the Schengen states is indeed the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust is based on mutual obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates air leaks, the entire system becomes faulty.
It should therefore be possible for other states to respond to this failure by re-establishing temporary and strictly controlled border checks.
In doing so, these failing states will be clearly invited to better control their external borders.

Moreover, as presented by the Commission, these measures will fully respect the spirit of Schengen, insofar as these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be made at the European level and not at the intergovernmental level.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to all measures envisaged in the long term with a view to a common migration policy.
It is particularly essential to strengthen Frontex, to provide more solidarity, in conclusion, to support the states located at the external borders.
The situation in the Mediterranean in recent years has only highlighted a shortcoming in the Schengen acquis.
Madam President, in a few weeks, migrants from the countries bordering the Mediterranean have accounted for a significant percentage of annual French immigration.
This achievement is not static, but must, on the contrary, evolve.

I hope these proposals will be adopted quickly, in order to ensure better management of our Schengen area as soon as possible and, in doing so, ensure the security of our common external borders, thank you.
Mr President, the European Union has finally imposed sanctions on Syria.
But, unfortunately, it seems to be doing so with a trembling hand, carefully avoiding any criticism of the head of the Syrian regime.
This lack of determination and clarity is obviously interpreted by the protesters as a form of abandonment and by the authorities as an indulgence that allows them to intensify the struggle.
The repression is so cruel that it is impossible to imagine for a moment that, at the same time, Syria could be elected to sit on the United Nations Human Rights Council.
of the United Nations, while today the Syrian authorities are denying UN observers access to the city of Dehra, the scene of terrible violence against defenseless civilians.

The assassination at the Human Rights Council would be an insult to the victims and their families, an encouragement for this regime to use brutal force against its people, in disregard, quite rightly, of the values that the Human Rights Council is supposed to uphold.
Madam High Representative, what diplomatic options are you considering to avoid such a disaster?

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to start by congratulating my colleague Carlos Coelho, who has done some truly outstanding work on this report, and it was very complicated, as God is my witness.
Bulgaria and Romania have made considerable efforts to strengthen control of their borders and have succeeded.
Whether it is police and judicial cooperation, data protection, visa policy, or the control of air, sea or land borders, the latest assessments are very clear.
All technical criteria are met.
We can only acknowledge this state of affairs.
Bulgaria and Romania are now in a position to implement this Schengen acquis in terms of both technology and personnel.
Moreover, while there are currently no obstacles preventing the enlargement of the Schengen area, we note that a number of recommendations have been addressed to these two countries.

I hope that these recommendations will be strictly followed up, especially with regard to the borders between Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey, because, as you know, mutual trust between Schengen States is based on the full compliance by these States with their reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations, it creates air leaks, and the entire system becomes faulty.
I sincerely hope that an agreement will be reached in the Council to welcome these two countries into the privileged circles of the Schengen States.
And we will all measure, in this chamber, the impact of this type of decision on the citizens concerned.
Once again, bravo to Mr. Coelho for his report, Mr. President.
Mr President, in its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has set itself the goal of making our economy greener and our transport more modern.
All European institutions have broadly supported this objective, including almost all the Member States and our Parliament.
In this context, it is therefore regrettable that, since 2008, several Member States have worked to strip the new Eurovignette Directive proposal of its content and block this issue.

Today, however, thanks to the perseverance of our rapporteur - and I would like to pay tribute here to Saeed El Khadraoui - thanks to his perseverance and that of the shadow rapporteurs in their negotiations with the Council, we finally have a compromise before us.

So, admittedly, this text is much less ambitious than the initial proposal, but it will allow for the first time to put into practice the polluter pays principle and to internalize external costs of transport, such as noise or CO2 emissions.

In order for this Eurovignette to be more than just a tax, but to actually contribute to improving transport in Europe, Member States are also encouraged to reinvest the money collected in modernizing transport modes.
Parliament has also managed to achieve concrete progress in the interoperability of toll systems, as well as stronger incentives for the use of less polluting heavy goods vehicles.

In order to remain consistent with the political objectives set by our institution, I sincerely hope that we will be able to adopt the compromise proposed to us in second reading and thus pave the way for a more sustainable transport policy.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I agree that, along with liberty and fraternity, there should be equality with the peasants and the countries that have rejoined, with the countries coming back from the East.
Yes, I agree with you.
I believe we have taken a major step forward with this report.
It wasn't easy at first and we were more in a confrontation, but we reached a consensus, and that's the most important thing.
This consensus helps to protect the overall project, and I believe that this is the great merit of the European Parliament.
We succeeded in this endeavor, and it was not easy, so I would like to thank the rapporteur Mercedes and all the parliamentarians.
First step.
In this text, we reaffirm the need for both equality, justice, and fairness between producers and between territories, and I believe this is important.
We have said very clearly and confirmed the maintenance and development of small farms, taking into account the importance of small farms for the quality and biodiversity of the territories.
I believe that was also fundamental.
The introduction of the concept of making agriculture agronomic, and turning the page on industrial, productivist agriculture, has been enshrined in the texts.
Now we need to implement this, it is a condition for making agriculture possible for future generations.
This is not an ideological issue.
Finally, today, our concern is that there are indeed threats to the budget.
This must be answered clearly.

Now, what we are waiting for is for us to actually enter the second phase, which is clearly the legislative debate, because beyond the texts and the grand intentions, it is in the legislative debate that we will truly see where we are going, and that is what we are obviously waiting for now.
I would like to finish by letting out a cry of anger against Germany's attitude, which has resulted in a reduction of five in food aid to the poorest in Europe.
It was within the CAP budget.
I want us to find a way to help the poorest people. There are 80 million European citizens who do not eat properly.
Mr President, while the European Parliament can boast of some significant advances in economic governance, I urge my colleagues to show humility, because we are dancing on the edge of the abyss.
Let us be well aware of two things.
The first is that the European Parliament remained inaudible during the Greek crisis.
While we are usually so quick to react to all kinds of events with resolutions all over the world, this existential crisis seems to leave us at a loss.
I deeply regret that we were unable to send a strong, concrete, and simple message to the Greeks, the governments of the member states, and European citizens.
The second observation concerns the scope of this package.
By voting for what I want, these six directives or regulations, we will certainly take the eurozone one step forward.
Not one step further towards a discipline that we have so sorely missed, one step, I say, nothing more, which will demonstrate its usefulness in the future.
But one need only look at the heated discussions surrounding the reversed qualified majority to measure the distance we still have to travel, when it should be about rules and automatic sanctions.
The mechanism of reversed qualified majority continues to act as a bogeyman for some.
We must, however, remain firm on the principle.
On a strictly political level, I regret that the left benches continue to reject the principles of sound budgetary management against all evidence.
Yes, deficit and sustainable growth are antonyms.

Yes, states must also manage their budget like a good family man, but not by stimulating the economy through public spending. This is a sweet poison in the short term, but it is never a sustainable solution.
As the coming weeks prove crucial, today it is a matter of refounding an economic Union
This morning, after three years of work, we voted on a text that is very important for the progress of consumer protection in Europe.
It rightly focuses on online shopping, which may, in twenty years, account for 25% of all commerce in Europe, which is quite considerable.
These jassas will notably be cross-border.
They will allow consumers to have a wider choice and also to pay much less.
This is real progress.
For SMEs, for all craftsmen, it is also a very important opportunity to expand their market.

Among the main advances, I would like to mention just two: the withdrawal period is extended to fourteen days, and all the information and the total price to be paid are recapitulated before the final step of placing the order.

And finally, I am proud, in the context of these explanations of vote, to say that I, but all our colleagues, voted unanimously across the political groups, because on such a subject, it was not polemics that we needed, but obviously consensus.
We are the ones who obtained it.

Madam President, Commissioners, I would first like to commend the efforts of our colleague Carlos Coelho on this very difficult issue that requires great skill, a lot of work, and a deep understanding of the subject matter.
The control of our common territory and our European borders is one of the most important challenges we face, and technology is more than ever at the service of this challenge.
In fact, over the past few years, we have witnessed an unprecedented development of European databases and the exchange of personal data.
What some are calling a digital tsunami is sure to become a reality in the coming years.
The SIS, VIS and EURODAC are all essential instruments today for ensuring the security of our European citizens.
Ensuring good operational management of these databases is therefore a major issue to which it is our responsibility to provide an effective response.

This response is of course very delicate and Carlos Cuello had to overcome numerous legal, institutional, budgetary, political and technical obstacles, and he has, despite everything, managed to produce a balanced text that satisfies all the parties concerned.
The creation of this agency for networks appears to be the best solution for ensuring the internal security of the member states.
No other existing institution or agency could take charge of the proper management of these information systems today.

It will improve the management of existing information systems, it will offer better synergy between these databases and will also allow for the integration of instruments that will be adopted in the future.
One of the very delicate questions that arose in this matter was the location of the agency: where should it be established?
Estonia and France are the only two countries that have put themselves forward as candidates to host it.

France already hosts the Schengen Information System in Strasbourg, where it has been managing its operational and administrative aspects since 1995, and as a result, it has full technical control over it.
Following the conclusions of the European Council in December 2003, which gave priority to the new Member States, Estonia also wanted to host the headquarters of this future agency.

Mr President, I believe that the compromise reached is very good. A kind of distribution of tasks has taken place, I shall conclude, Madam President, by transferring the agency's headquarters to Tallinn, where governance, strategy and programme design tasks will be carried out.
The development and operation of the systems will take place in Strasbourg.

The cost-effectiveness ratio is very well balanced and this compromise solution in no way calls into question the centralized management of IT systems. Madam President, I am very pleased to have spoken to you about this report.
Mr President, the horizontal social clause and Article 14 of the Lisbon Treaty provide binding guarantees for social rights, including the right of access to services of general interest.
It is time to prove to European citizens that social Europe is on the move.

Our social achievements must therefore be given the place they deserve in Community law, by recognising the specific nature of SSIs in relation to competition rules, bearing in mind that these services have strong local roots and rely on social economy players.

Mr. De Rossa's report is an opportunity to reaffirm the simple yet powerful principles of equality, universality, and access to these collectively organized services, which are drivers of well-being and social progress.
Commissioner, you said it was time to move on to the practicalities.
Yes, it is time to move on to concrete measures, so I propose that, in this debate, we genuinely support a European legislative instrument for social services.
I therefore invite you to vote for the alternative resolution tabled by the Greens.
Mr President, debates on GMOs must be based on irrefutable arguments, both scientifically and legally.
Legally, a wide range of solid arguments were needed for Member States wishing to restrict or ban GMOs on their territory.
The rapporteur has broadened the range of options available, but it remains limited nonetheless.
- I don't know.
This basic scientific file must also be irrefutable.
The Council has repeatedly challenged EFSA's scientific assessments, which have always been positive towards GMOs, in contrast to national scientific assessments.

To restore confidence, would it not be necessary, first and foremost, Commissioner, to simply apply the existing legislation, which aims to provide a great deal of scientific guarantees, particularly in terms of long-term impact assessment?
Why have the Council's recommendations of October 2008 remained unimplemented?
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, first of all, I would like to thank our colleague Simon Busuttil for the tremendous work he has accomplished.
These reflections have enriched the initial proposal and we can only congratulate her for that.
This report outlines for us an agency with increased resources, more in line with the missions assigned to it.
Recent events have demonstrated the need for closer cooperation between the European Union, the Member States, and the support of a strong agency.
Frontex finally gets the means to fulfill its missions.
By being able to acquire or rent its own equipment and benefit from the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and very effective.
New tasks are also assigned to them, such as organizing voluntary returns or processing personal data so that we can combat cross-border crime while protecting fundamental rights.

This extension of Frontex's scope of competence enables us to consider and address migration issues through a comprehensive approach, rather than confining ourselves to a mere mechanical border management.
I approve the possibility of exchanging personal data with other European agencies, including Europol.
Finally, the human dimension has taken its rightful place in this report.
A strong recognition of human rights is guaranteed by the proposal to establish an advisory board within the Agency.

I can only welcome this comprehensive proposal that takes a step forward towards a sound and responsible management of our external borders, in a context where migratory pressures are particularly strong and continuous. Thank you.

Mr President, I should like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Meyer, and my fellow Members for their comments, which have sometimes been critical, but this 2010 annual report is finally a great opportunity to talk about the Committee on Petitions, as it remains too little known.
However, it is the Commission, which has a direct, sometimes physical, connection with the citizen, that can attend our debates in person.
She has undeniable legitimacy in Parliament, as well as extensive expertise, thanks to her direct relationship with citizens.
In fact, any petitioner can go to Parliament and defend their rights before the petitions committee.
One can also praise the serenity of the debates despite the painful cases that are often addressed.
This Commission represents Europe as it should be: listening to the problems of its citizens and united in finding solutions and protecting them.
Unfortunately, the means of action and the means of exerting influence remain limited, particularly with regard to the environmental risk of projects that are sometimes almost completed.
But I also see it when it comes to defending specific cases, such as family rights or children's rights in the event of a divorce.
We will also be conducting a mission on this topic in November.
I also regret that national authorities do not always rush to provide us with all the necessary information.
I would like to thank the European Commission for the research and verification work it carries out, even if sometimes it could go further in the search for truth.
I must also acknowledge the constructive work we are doing with the European Ombudsman.
Finally, I appeal to citizens to continue to contact us through petitions as our directly elected representatives.
Our role will always be to safeguard your interests in strict compliance with European law.
Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome this resolution on homelessness because it is our responsibility to remind everyone of its extreme urgency.
Let us first note that what was a priority yesterday remains so even more prejudicially today.

The lack of a definition and reliable statistical indicators on sans-bbrisme cannot prevent us from noting that, as the crisis worsens, the number of people living below the poverty line has increased, according to Eurostat, from 79 million in 2009 to an estimated 84 million in 2011.
Dear colleagues, three years ago, our Parliament, concerned about eradicating poverty, asked the Member States to put an end to the problem of STF by 2015.
Today, we have ourselves come somewhat closer to our goal.

Has the year 2010, dedicated to the fight against poverty, really been put to good use by the member states to concretely address this widespread precariousness, the urgency of which has become permanent?
I genuinely doubt it and I deeply regret it.

Finally, I would like to emphasize the need to develop a comprehensive, multisectoral strategy to address homelessness, because of course, there is poverty and lack of housing, but there are also family problems, health issues, various addictions, and personal vulnerabilities.
A comprehensive, effective, ambitious, yet tailored approach is needed, one that takes into account the individuals, the heterogeneous nature of their experiences, and the disruption in their lives.
It is a right, at the very least a fundamental one, from which many of the most vulnerable are deprived.
Madam President, as everyone has said, in recent years the European Union has been hit by unprecedented disasters, and listing them all would take up the entire debate.
I will still mention the explosion in Azed F, the tenth anniversary of which we commemorated less than a week ago in Toulouse.
A reinforced reaction at European level, as proposed in Mrs. Gardini's report, represents a real opportunity to demonstrate solidarity between our populations.

For several years now, the Union has been trying to make this pooling of our efforts operational, and it is now time to act together and not wait for another catastrophe to strike our territories before we learn from it.
Today, it is a matter of making our material, human, and financial resources available to everyone in order to prevent new tragedies from occurring.
Commissioner, earlier you said that we need to anticipate risks.

And it is truly regrettable that, in this context, the European Commission is considering withdrawing funding from the GMES satellite observation program, which is recognized by all as an essential instrument for preventing and coordinating disaster responses.
I urge the Commission to reconsider this position and to support these flagship programs that provide Europe with undeniable added value.
There, I would like to thank Mrs. Gardini for her excellent report.
I hope we will adopt it, as it will pave the way for European solidarity in the service of the citizen. Thank you.
Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, the number of poor and unemployed people continues to rise within the European Union.
More than 43 million Europeans are threatened by food poverty.
The situation is serious.
Today, six member states want to end the food aid program without any replacement: Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and the Czech Republic.
Certainly, there is a decision from the Court of Justice and we must respect it.
However, Commissioner, Parliament questioned you last July, at the initiative of our Green group, and you made relevant proposals to safeguard the programme.
The Greens are ready to work with you on long-term solutions, but when millions of people depend on this system, we cannot allow the food aid budget to be cut by four.
The emergency is real.
If nothing is done by the end of the year, food banks will be missing out on more than 300 million euros, and there is no guarantee that national governments will be able to step in to fill this gap.
It is therefore a real question of solidarity between peoples.
Let us not allow a minority of irresponsible governments to deprive millions of Europeans of food aid, because this is first and foremost a matter of survival.
The fight against poverty and malnutrition also requires a reform of the CAP.
We must fundamentally change the way we produce food in order to bring food production closer to the people, especially the poorest, who also have the right to a healthy and balanced diet.
Only a truly sustainable CAP will enable us to ensure that fewer Europeans will need food aid.
The Council must come to its senses and allow those in need to access this vital aid.
I am particularly addressing the future Danish government, which will be responsible for ensuring the presidency of the European Union starting in January.
Does it take food riots in Europe to realize the urgent need to change our logic?

When it comes to saving banks, the Council knows how to find solutions, but when it comes to saving food banks, there is no one left. The Parliament sent a strong message last time: human beings are more important than finance.
finance, it is high time to reaffirm it.
In any case, we will be very vigilant and we will not fail to renew our appeal in a constructive manner.
Indeed, six Member States hold in their hands the fate of 18 million Europeans in need.
Six Member States that claim they are doing nothing more or less than legalism.
Legalism is one thing, humanism and political choices are another.
How can we not express our anger towards those who remain deaf to the alarm calls made by associations that help the most deprived?

And do we, as Members of the European Parliament, representatives of all citizens, want a Europe where national selfishness dictates policies, paying little heed to the citizens of countries in budgetary difficulty?
There is no question of renationalizing this aid.

No, let's maintain this program, give it a stronger legal basis, but let's not abandon those who, in the immediate term, in 2012, are counting on this aid during particularly difficult times of crisis.

Mr President, Commissioner, I will not dwell on the cynicism with which the ArcelorMittal group announced the closure of some of its facilities in Europe and, in particular, in Belgium, in Liège, ultimately leading to hundreds of direct layoffs and putting several thousand indirect jobs at risk.
As a Liège native, I share the astonishment and dismay of the 581 workers who have been laid off from their family.
But I am also thinking of the severe restructuring announced by the steel group in France, Germany and Luxembourg.
The reasons cited are always the same: poor prospects for the steel market in Europe, fierce competition from imports from China and Korea.
Russia and Brazil, the reduction in the automotive market and finally the competitiveness gap, for example, between the Liège site and the best factories in Northern Europe.
In addition, despite a difficult 2010, the financial center of the Belgian steel group Arcelor Mittal generated a profit of 1.394 billion euros.
He paid zero euros in taxes, resulting in a tax rate of zero.
This is particularly shocking.
Group management is primarily financial, with a stop-and-go policy implemented across several sites.
In the minds of these leaders, the closure of sites is nothing more than an economic adjustment variable where human issues are of little importance.
This is no longer acceptable.
You spoke, Commissioner, about the rules.
Is it not time for the Commission to develop a binding code of social responsibility for multinational corporations?

It has been six years since our Parliament adopted a report on relocation, the code of conduct for companies, the reimbursement of subsidies, and mandatory consultation between companies, trade unions, and public authorities.
Since then, it must be acknowledged that little concrete progress has been made on these various proposals.
So, what does the Commission intend to do about this and within what timeframe?
If we are to support the competitiveness of businesses and make Europe attractive in terms of economic investment, we must also adopt a legislative framework.
Europe needs to be strong to cope with relocation and restructuring, and to ensure that another form of capital, human capital, is fully taken into account.
Finally, in the case of the Liège site, I hope it will be able to benefit from the intervention of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to compensate the workers who have been made redundant. Thank you.

Madam President, my dear colleagues, the wave of layoffs that is affecting workers across Europe must lead us to reflect on the role that we, as political leaders, have to play in the face of multinational companies that act...

without any social ethics, which carries out stock market layoffs and relocates to reduce costs, increase shareholder profits, and please rating agencies, disregarding social and environmental standards.

In its resolution of 20 September last on the future of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, Parliament clearly expressed its desire to support, above all, the workers affected by the negative effects of restructuring.
But we have also asked the Commission to ensure consistency between the EGF's interventions and the European Union's industrial policy, particularly through the use of structural funds.

We also insisted that the future EGF regulation include improvements so that the Fund does not produce the same random, moral effects on multinational companies that it does today, as is the case with ArcelorMittal and Nokia.
Commissioner, we can no longer continue to look separately at the issue of structural funds and the globalisation adjustment fund without
without taking into account the restructuring strategies of companies that benefit from it, without examining the cost-benefit ratio of a policy, I repeat,
Mr President, the European Ombudsman conducts investigations into complaints against the institutions and bodies of the European Union with great success.

This instrument is both necessary to facilitate the free movement of our businesses and citizens, but it is also a formidable guarantee, especially in the face of the Union's detractors who all too often say that the European Union is nothing more than a bureaucratic machine without control.
It is clearly nonsensical. Europe is genuinely working on itself, thanks to the European Mediators, among others.
But let me relay a finding that I deeply regret, in which the Commission is under fire for criticism.
First, there are the figures of 65 and the actual figure, not 12, of investigations opened by the Ombudsman concerning the European Commission.

There are also representatives from numerous companies who come to us to explain their lack of understanding of the Commission, of a European Commission that remains deaf to their requests, particularly regarding access to documents. The same applies to the issue of transparency in decision-making.
Few people understand it.
And finally, from personal experience, I must admit that I have sometimes been shocked by the reactions of certain European Commission services present in the Committee on Petitions.
As you know, the European Commission provides us with its position on petitions, a position that we always take into account and which is necessary.

But occasionally, one sees representatives of the European Commission who refuse to answer a Member's questions or who hide behind empty platitudes almost as well as politicians and present themselves to citizens pleading their cause.

I therefore wanted to remind you that Europe must have a human face, that behind the administrative problems identified and resolved by the Ombudsman are Europeans who are relieved to be heard but disappointed by

This behavior of citizens is then negatively marked by their confrontation with the institutions, potentially creating a sense of revolt, incomprehension, and, in the long term, perhaps even Euroscepticism.
I sincerely hope that these criticisms and those of the Ombudsman against the institutions in general are heard. Thank you.
Madam President, professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and competitiveness of our European Union, these are indeed the terms in which today's topic is framed.
We, the EPP Group, have supported the report by our colleague, Mrs McLaughlin, a report in the development of which we have played a significant role and which we obviously support.

This is the main recommendation of this report for greater professional mobility, more simplification and efficiency in the procedures for recognizing professional qualifications, while ensuring patient safety and consumer safety.
But it is in terms of the path to growth that the challenge of increasing professional mobility arises.
Moreover, the Forum for a Single Market, held in Krakow at the beginning of October, was well aware of this.

who pointed out that the Member States had to recognise the potential of the internal market for boosting growth and job creation and had to act to remove all obstacles to the completion of the internal market.
The European Council of October 23rd also established as one of the essential priorities for achieving smart, sustainable growth.

This includes, in particular, the implementation of the twelve priority proposals in the Single Market Act, the twelve proposals made by the Commission, including the recognition of professional qualifications.

We can clearly see that it is by increasing professional mobility that we can hope to unlock the growth potential contained in the internal market, our internal market of 500 million inhabitants, 500 million consumers.

Professional mobility must therefore not only ensure, if we strengthen it, modernize it, and improve it, the free movement of our compatriots within this market, but also, we hope, acquire additional margins of growth.
That is why we particularly want to emphasize a practical recommendation: we, the PPE, have specifically supported the implementation of a voluntary pre-positioning policy.
Madam President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Cashmarck, for his excellent work.
I would like to say that it is important that each year the European Parliament draws up a report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, insofar as
This assembly plays a crucial role in strengthening the North-South dialogue and in establishing a development policy based on partnership and exchange.
The year 2010 was a significant year for the PPE, which met twice, as the predecessors mentioned, in Spain and the DRC, to discuss various topics.
on the impact of climate change in ACP countries, the impact of the global crisis, or on media freedom and independence and food security.
But in 2010, the EPP also sent its first election observation mission of this legislative term.
I had the honour of co-chairing this mission in Burundi for the presidential elections with my colleague Assaride, a Member of Parliament from Mali.
This election observation mission was a resounding success.

We were able to meet all the political stakeholders involved and, thanks to the dual origin of this ACP delegation, both European and African, we embodied a legitimacy different from that of European or African missions.

I therefore invite the EPP Bureau to renew this experience, which provides an opportunity to put into practice the solidarity and privileged relations that unite the European Union with the ACP countries.
I would like to thank Mr. Dardenne for his very interesting report.
Certainly, the crisis is economic and financial, but above all, for our fellow citizens, it is a social crisis.
Reducing the number of people in precarious situations by 20 million by 2020 requires strong measures involving different levels of public authority.

We need more than ever to fulfill the commitments made by the European Union in 2010, during the European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion and the creation of the European Platform against Poverty and Social Exclusion, in order to have a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We must perpetuate and optimize European funds, particularly the aid program for the most deprived, which is currently maintained, improve social protection, and support local or national initiatives that develop services for the care of children, the elderly, and dependent persons.
Poverty is a scourge to be fought at a horizontal level and it is now time to act to enable the most deprived to escape their precarious situation.

And we must, as political leaders at the European, national and local levels, take the necessary measures to ensure that they have access to housing, healthcare, justice, education and a first job without discrimination, with a minimum income that can be indexed according to the poverty rate of each Member State.
Investing in the promotion of innovation and social experimentation and in the reduction of poverty will enable us to implement a strategy of sustainable, intelligent and inclusive growth.
The Europe we want and need today is a Europe of solidarity.
Mr President, I would first of all like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Levin, for her excellent work.

As the draftsperson of the opinion of the Committee on Development, I am pleased that the Committee on Fisheries has taken up the elements contained in our opinion, because it is crucial that the development dimension
be taken into account in measures to combat illegal fishing at global level, in the name of policy coherence and close links with development policy.
Indeed, the fight against illegal fishing requires comprehensive solutions and the involvement of all states, including developing ones.
However, it is necessary that the technical and financial capacities of the states are also taken into account in the actions to be undertaken.
Indeed, one cannot impose the same constraints without accompanying measures on developed or developing countries.
Small island states, for example, have very limited capacities.
They must therefore be supported in their efforts to combat illegal fishing.
This is why the Union will need to increase the financial envelope for the fisheries sector when it concludes agreements in this area in developing countries.

Furthermore, it is crucial that measures to combat illegal fishing are implemented, as this practice undermines the development of countries by reducing the financial resources that these countries could derive from the fishing industry.
Or, these resources are necessary for developing countries to implement social, economic, and education policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union promotes, when implementing these measures to combat illegal fishing in developing countries, the involvement of civil society and businesses alongside the beneficiary states.
A holistic approach is necessary to stem the tide of illegal fishing. Thank you.
Mr President, I would like to say that it is largely thanks to these outermost regions that the European Union is the world's leading maritime power.
This is a major asset for Europe, and the development and implementation of a comprehensive policy on the sea, oceans, and seabed are essential for the future.
But I fear that with 20 or 50 million euros, this will not be necessary, nor sufficient to achieve this great challenge.
The fight against illegal fishing is part of this broader policy, and it is urgent at the European level to find an adequate solution to this problem, particularly through international cooperation.
I would also like to point out that the maritime zones of Guadeloupe, French Guiana, Martinique, Mayotte, and Réunion are regularly violated and plundered.
Since the report does not mention this, I take this opportunity to draw the attention of my colleagues and the Commission to this particular problem.
Madam President, I would first like to commend the Polish presidency for its dynamism and determination.
Next week, at the Council, our heads of state and government will have to make essential decisions for the future of the eurozone, for the future of the Union.
They will also have to seriously address the relaunch of growth.

That said, we can clearly see that financial stability has become the top priority today, and the pressures and tensions exerted from outside the eurozone countries, as well as within the eurozone, are ruining our credibility and undermining trust.
To hope for a return of confidence, it is necessary to restore financial stability, break the terrible progression of national deficits and sovereign debts.
Financial stability has indeed become the priority of priorities, it has become an ardent obligation for all.

Moreover, our democracies have all embarked on very courageous programs to clean up their public finances and reduce their debt, but financial stability is also a prerequisite for any resumption of growth.
But who says solidarity, who says financial stability, budgetary discipline because they go hand in hand, of course, must also say solidarity.
We believe it is important to ensure this dual movement of financial stability, budgetary discipline, and solidarity.
A final word on democracy.
Be careful not to disempower our democratic institutions.

Rather than thinking about resorting to a jurisdictional mechanism to sanction budget overruns, I would suggest that we consider mechanisms of control and sanctions carried out by democratic institutions.

To be perfectly honest, I am not the spokesperson for the French Minister of Foreign Affairs, and, quite frankly, even though I belong to the same political party as him, I am not constantly, I would say, in a position to relay the statements of the French Minister of Foreign Affairs.
To be completely honest once again, I am not aware of any recent statements by Alain Juppé to that effect.
I simply think that France's current position is to constantly reaffirm that the euro is truly the heart of our European construction, that the preservation of the euro,

I mean the preservation of this common project and the preservation of the European Union. In this movement to safeguard the euro, we must of course think about the future, think about protecting the younger generations and preserving peace on our continent.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will be voting for the third time on the new development cooperation instrument.
the development, which provides accompanying measures in the banana sector for ACP countries exporting bananas, following the reduction of their tariff preferences, the BAM.
This aid program has a budget of 190 million euros and targets ten ACP countries until 2013.
It is of crucial importance for our African and Caribbean partners, as the banana sector has a significant economic and social impact in these countries.
While I deeply regret that not all of Parliament's demands regarding the implementation of delegated acts have been incorporated into this instrument.
We have nevertheless managed to make progress.
Indeed, the text provides clear objectives and precise criteria for the allocation of resources to the Commission.
The Commission also made a statement specifying the methodology used.

Furthermore, we have a Council statement on the next multiannual financial framework specifying that the latter will duly take into account the delegated acts in the instruments of external aid after 2013.
Finally, in its resolution, Parliament specifies - and I consider this point to be crucial - that this is in no way a precedent.

And I would like to tell you that I have just returned from Togo, where the 22nd session of the ACP-EU PA was held, and I believe I can tell you that our ACP friends are counting on us given the urgency of the situation.
The funds should have been released two years ago.
We must be aware of the disastrous consequences for our ACP partners if the BAM ICD were rejected.
The situation for some farmers is dramatic, we can no longer wait and must act accordingly.
I am therefore counting on you to support the text. Thank you.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our coordinator, Mr Tissbergmann, is unfortunately unable to be here this evening due to personal reasons.
However, I know that he fully shares my analysis on this issue.

The conciliation on this legislative package was long and tedious, and while the result on the human rights instruments and ICI plus is satisfactory, we are very far from achieving the desired outcome regarding the banana instrument.

Thus, the compromise reached on this text dismisses with a wave of the hand the mandate that had been given to our negotiating team, which was to place Parliament on the same level as the Council on all programming decisions concerning the choice of strategic priorities and financial allocations.
Because it is indeed the powers of our Assembly and the very spirit of the Lisbon Treaty that are in question here.
The choice of programming priorities is a highly political decision on which our Assembly must have a say.
By categorically refusing to recognize any supervisory power for Parliament and resorting to shameful blackmail, the Council has once again demonstrated a reprehensible ideological retreat.
But the Member States must understand that the European Union's external action is now a shared competence between our institutions.
That is why our Parliament must remain sovereign and reject the proposal on the banana instrument.
This is the only way we can show the Council and the Commission that Parliament wants more transparency in Community decisions.
If we lose this battle, the absurdity would be that we would have to wait for a new treaty to finally obtain the powers that the Lisbon Treaty already provides for.
Mr President, at the risk of shocking the most federalist among you, I believe that defence policy is an eminently national policy.
It meets the strategic, diplomatic, and security needs specific to each nation.
Sharing capabilities is nothing other than an amputation of sovereignty. The single market for military equipment is a vast joke when some member states believe that
Defense is guaranteed in Washington, and is primarily equipped with American materials, as Europe is unable, in this field as in so many others, to impose Community preference.
Regarding the common security challenges of the EU member states, there is nothing that cannot be resolved through intergovernmental cooperation, without any intervention from Brussels.

I am sorry, but entrusting these areas to Mrs. Ashton would be tantamount to acknowledging that Moody's and Standard & Poor's have the legitimacy to judge our economic policies, to accept that the Mercosur couple could impose a German Europe on twenty-seven peoples, a pure mental aberration.

For thirty years, and even more so since the disappearance of the Soviet threat, defense budgets have been the first to be sacrificed on the altar of budgetary austerity, to the point of rendering most of our military tools obsolete.

deficient or outdated, and this in the name of purely financial considerations, with each one expecting the neighbor or the supposed American big brother to make the efforts that it is no longer prepared to make itself.
But you are mistaken about the voice.

Only by returning to independent and resolute national policies will we be able to individually equip ourselves with the means necessary not only for our national security and interests, but also for the cooperation of these means to meet common challenges.
A sum of weaknesses and shortcomings has never made a strength.

Mr President, I wanted to express the support of the French delegation of the EPP Group for the Treaty on Stability, Coordination and Governance in the Economic Union and its support for the main conclusions reached by the Council.
Make no mistake.
This treaty represents an important step towards greater economic and fiscal integration, towards greater financial stability.
Let's say it again here.
There can be no sustainable recovery of growth and employment without the sanitisation of our public finances.
Of course, growth cannot be decreed; it is not a treaty that, on its own, can revive growth.
But a treaty, that is to say a set of mutual rules and commitments, can bring confidence and responsibility.

Since the president of the Socialist group saw fit to introduce party politics into this chamber and to allude to the upcoming French presidential campaign, mentioning the Socialist candidate for this French presidential election, I wanted to respond.
We, the EPP, consider the statements of the French socialist candidate, who declared his intention to renegotiate the treaty concluded by, to be totally irresponsible.
Renegotiate what and with whom.
These words are totally irresponsible.
They pay little heed to the French state's word, to the respect of the French state's commitments.

Madame Ashton, Madagascar, one of the poorest countries in the world, is experiencing a political crisis whose resolution will depend on the implementation of the roadmap leading up to the presidential and legislative elections.
The cross-section of this country is negative.
In normal times, our contribution is around 50% of the country's budget.
The European Union has rightly suspended its budget support for the ninth and tenth EDFs, but not for the MDGs.
Meanwhile, the population is suffering and companies based in Madagascar are sometimes forced to contribute despite themselves.

While supporting your position, we would like you to use all your influence with the SADC to ensure that the legal and judicial tangle surrounding the return of the former president is resolved as soon as possible, as this is one of the most sensitive aspects of implementing this roadmap.

I would like to hear your opinion on the matter and also inform you that the European Union-Madagascar Friendship Group, which we have just created in the European Parliament, is available to work with you and the Commission in the interests of the Malagasy people and in defense of the values of our Union.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to commend the rapporteur, Mr Iturgaiz, for the quality of his work, for the long negotiation process he had to undertake and for the patience he has shown.

We are finally getting to the vote on this report, which is extremely important because it allows us to bring the difficulties and concerns of our fellow citizens to this chamber, to the Commission and to the Council.
This is further proof, if any were needed, of the effectiveness of the right to petition in Europe.
Environmental petitions are in the majority, and waste is a major concern for our fellow citizens.
This topic must address a societal problem.
We consume in Tuva.
We are only now realizing that what we don't consume, we throw away.
This awareness must absolutely be reinforced among citizens, that is clear.
But this report is also a wake-up call for the member states.
It is still worrying to see that the states seem not to be in control of the situation.
Only six Member States have transposed the Waste Framework Directive on time.
The number of complaints received on the subject sometimes demonstrates the lack of transparency in the choice of landfill sites.
Finally, and most worryingly, organized crime seems to be doing whatever it wants.
A market worth 75 billion euros inevitably attracts covetous eyes.
States must send a strong signal.
Sanctions against companies that divert public contracts to enrich themselves must be increased.
This report is a warning signal to the states, but the European Commission must also play its role and verify the proper implementation of waste directives.
This dossier must be made visible, but also credible.
If no one plays the game, we will continue to waste time and money on verification and counter-verification procedures that may last for years.
Let us listen to the petitioners' message and stop this waste more quickly.
Commissioner, rapporteur, I would first like to congratulate Mr Nicholson for the courage he has shown in the face of the Council and the Commission.
Despite this, I fear that what we have ended up with does not allow for a balance between producers and manufacturers.
This agreement reminds me of that illusion we are familiar with, which children tell us about, of a paradise where vegetarian lions would graze next to sheep.
I don't believe it for a second. Since 2003, Mrs. Fischer Boel has done everything to ideologically destroy the dairy quotas.
In October 2009, the Court of Auditors, despite everything, recognized the effectiveness of these milk quotas.

Or, today, we are in an even more dramatic situation, and we can see what is happening in Denmark, where the most solid farms, with the increase in production, are all in a state of bankruptcy, with the price of land falling by 40%.
Do we want this for the European level?
I say no, we must control production with the participation of the public authorities. Thank you.
Commissioner, the personal data protection standards of third countries still differ considerably from European standards.
It is, however, our duty to ensure that our European minimum protection standards, which we uphold, are respected and guaranteed to European citizens.
It is fundamental that personal data are processed fairly and collected for specified and legitimate purposes.
European citizens must be guaranteed the right to access and rectify their personal data, as well as the right to file a legal complaint in the event of a violation of their rights.
Action must be taken to allow European and international standards to coexist and to resolve a potential legal conflict that could harm European citizens.
European legislation alone is not enough.
It must articulate and coexist intelligently with international standards, because we cannot shirk our duties and commitments to European citizens.
This situation echoes other debates within this chamber.
It reminds us of the relevance of projects such as the establishment of a European programme for monitoring the financing of terrorism.
Such a system would provide us with a tool that has proven effective in the United States, while fully respecting domestic law and, consequently, the protection of European citizens' personal data.
The European institutions must continue their commitment in this regard and fully assume their protection standards, thank you.
Mr President, first of all, thank you to the rapporteurs for their work.

In response to the crisis, the European Union has spent over a year strengthening its economic governance to avoid macroeconomic imbalances and excessive budget deficits threatening the European economy, but this has not prevented social exclusion or the increase in unemployment.
It is time, no, it is now urgent that the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy become an absolute priority for the European Commission and for the Member States, with a view to growth.

Each state will have to implement a national employment plan, which means that emphasis should be placed on topics such as blending, training, retraining, microcredit, apprenticeships, paid internships, etc.

Or, as Commissioner Andor pointed out earlier, we have 23 million unemployed people in Europe, but also 23 million SMEs and 23 billion euros of European funds dedicated to employment that are not being used.
We could almost make it a strategy 23
And that's not counting the 60 billion euros in unallocated cohesion funds.
In Denmark and the Netherlands, social initiatives have been implemented and have proven effective, based on flexicurity.
So let's take inspiration from it.

This also means that our social policy as a whole must be more tailored, with social incentives that are more advantageous than those related to unemployment and active support for all socially responsible businesses.
We had poverty reduction targets to meet by 2020, but we already know they will not be achieved due to the lack of strong and adequate measures taken by the member states.

Our role as parliamentarians must therefore be fully exercised, and it is our responsibility to demand that the same energy put into taking strong economic governance measures also applies to ambitious, effective, and binding social governance measures.
Madam President, undoubtedly, the women's cause owes a great deal to Europe.
The principle of gender equality was already enshrined in the Treaty of Rome and has been continuously reaffirmed in numerous treaties since then.
Gender equality is truly a fundamental value of our European project.
As a result, Europe has always been very proactive in working towards gender equality and the promotion of women's rights.
Little by little, progress has been made.
Numerous legislative instruments have been adopted, and directives have been implemented.
Right here, within our Parliament, there has been an extremely active and vigilant Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality for many years.
A European Institute for Gender Equality has been established.
Programs are being implemented, and financial resources are being allocated year after year.
More recently, on 2 March, we had the opportunity to celebrate the second edition of the European Day for Equal Treatment and Equal Pay.
a European Equal Pay Day. The legislative arsenal therefore exists, and the European will has been made concrete on several occasions.
However, it must be acknowledged that the fight for gender equality, particularly for equal pay, remains relevant today.
On average, there is always a wage gap of around
For equal work, women still earn 17% less than men.
This is, of course, completely unacceptable.
The Women's Committee of the Parliament is currently working on a draft resolution to call on the European Commission to revise the 2006 directive on gender equality.
The treatment, which is one of the most worrying issues and at the heart of the concerns and demands of European women in all our societies.
On another subject, the introduction of quotas, both within the decision-making bodies of large companies and in political life, I come from a country, France, which adopted this long ago.
ten years of binding quota rules in political life and, more recently, about a year ago, a law to establish quotas on the boards of large companies.
France is not the only country, of course, to have opted for such legislation.
What is the assessment after a few years of application in one case, a few months in another, forced to acknowledge that things have changed, that things have moved forward?
So, a necessary evil.
Quotas have an effect.

Commissioner, you recently took an important step towards establishing European-level quotas in the decision-making bodies of large companies by launching this major public consultation to gather opinions on the actions to be implemented, including potential legislative measures.
On this matter, you will have my full and complete support.
Mr President, Commissioner, on the occasion of this resolution, allow me to address two topics: first, the issue of water management in the world and in Europe.
Europe, and then a question to the European Commission so that measures can be taken to address a number of our concerns related to the common agricultural policy.
The issue, as we know, is that water is the major concern of the twenty-first century.
It is because we will have answers that we will have peace in the world and in Europe.
We know the stakes, we know the stakes in terms of management, we know the stakes in terms of food security.
And, as our colleague Rivasi pointed out during this forum, too many purely commercial concerns are at the heart of the discussion that has been taking place in Marseille in recent days.
A question: why is there no coherence between water management and water-related resources and the common agricultural policy?
Nothing in the CAP reform indicates anything about this management, as our colleague Sarboud said earlier.
Give us answers.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to start by thanking the rapporteur and our assistants for the work they have done.
This report now truly lives up to its name, which is to remove obstacles to citizenship.
Europe is a wonderful project, but it is all too often noted that it is not yet perfectly defined.
Take the economic crisis, for example.
It has exposed our weaknesses and enabled us to build our single market regulatory institutions more robustly.
For the European citizen, it's the same.
The Committee on Petitions, a veritable complaints office, records the grievances of our fellow citizens every day.
In three days, the European citizens' initiative will complete this framework.
Despite all our policies that call for mobility, membership, European values, and exchanges, there are still far too many obstacles to the exercise of citizenship.
A citizen who does not feel European is a citizen who will not vote, a citizen who will not see the benefits that Europe represents in their daily life.
Together with my fellow MEPs from the EPP, we have made a huge number of proposals, the most numerous, and I would like to thank them for that.
This is a report that should produce a sense of belonging and European identity that we need to recreate and maintain through these measures.
Our Europe must be a Europe that protects.
Commissioner Viviane Reding has made twenty-five very concrete proposals in favor of citizens.
They are essential for restoring trust between the citizen and Europe.
But the proposals in this report reflect other expectations of our fellow citizens: online shopping, moving house, children's rights, employment, health and safety.
citizen participation, healthcare abroad, twinning, minority rights, etc. We still struggle too much to fully benefit from the opportunities offered by Europe.
Rights are exercised, claims are heard.
We are the relays for this.
The European Year of Citizenship in 2013 must demonstrate to citizens that, along with free movement, there is also a free exercise of rights in Europe.
Mr President, I believe that taxation is an interesting tool for changing behaviour.

I believe that energy consumption should be accompanied by an indicative price signal for the consumer, and, above all, I think that, in order to avoid any distortion in the internal market, we must try to align our tax practices.
The principle of proportionality in the different levels of taxation on energy products therefore seems to me to be a necessity.
In the case at hand, for example, this would put an end to the diesel tourism that we are currently witnessing and which is not acceptable.
I therefore share the philosophy of the Commission's proposed directive revision.

Nevertheless, if we are to achieve our goals in terms of reducing CO2 emissions or improving energy efficiency, our collective decisions must not penalize citizens or sectors that are particularly exposed to pollution.

The volatility of prices on global markets, and I am thinking of the agricultural sector, for example. The proposed directive will have an impact, albeit differentiated according to the level of taxation in each Member State, but an impact nonetheless on the price of diesel.
The question is who, in the end, will have to bear this price increase?
Are there any real, practical, realistic alternatives that are accessible to consumers?
As the shadow rapporteur for the environment committee, I support an ambitious but above all sustainable position for everyone.

I therefore advocate for greater progressivity and for the proposal and its principle of proportionality to come into effect in 2030, subject to a new impact study, updating the one on which the Commission is based, which was carried out five years ago.

A month earlier, right here, we had a debate on the wave of layoffs in Europe due to the economic crisis, particularly at Arcelor, a multinational present in nine European member states, which is restructuring its production facilities in Europe in response to a demand for steel in Berne.
Since the shutdown of two blast furnaces in Belgium and Luxembourg, and the temporary closure of one in France, it is estimated that nearly 6 direct jobs will be at risk in 2012.

Beyond unacceptable practices, such as stop-and-go, which should be better regulated, there is the broader issue of European steel production and adaptation to change, which requires extremely urgent responses.

Six months ago, the Commission announced to us the need to conduct, in light of the economic crisis, a new consultation exercise for responsible management of restructuring with the social partners and public authorities.
My question is simple: six months later, where are we?
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to start by dispelling the unfounded allegations that between 500 and one million fake biometric passports are circulating in France.
France takes the risk of identity document fraud very seriously.
It does not take such offences lightly.
At the initiative of its government, identity theft is an offense punishable by one year in prison and a 15 euro fine.
The conditions for issuing identity documents have been simplified, allowing prefectures to free up additional resources to combat this fraud.
Thus, a fraud liaison officer is appointed in each prefecture.
In addition, the security measures for issuing identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, civil status data provided can be verified between administrative departments, as much as possible by dematerialized means, in order to limit the risks of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same rigor applies to the home address verification trap.
The Ministry of the Interior has embarked on a path towards increased security of proof of address with the insertion of a bar code.

The standard processing of a title application includes authorized consultation of relevant files, comparison of all documents submitted in previous title applications, and possible authentication of supporting documents.

The security of the issuance of documents is further guaranteed by the applicant's dual appearance at the time of application submission and subsequently at the time of document collection, as well as the taking of two digital fingerprints.
And that's not to mention the enhanced checks for renewing lost and stolen titles for comparative purposes with the data kept by the prefectures, I conclude.

Furthermore, France informs international cooperation bodies, particularly Interpol, I am finishing, Mr. President, I have almost finished, of the passports issued or lost and stolen so that they are not used for fraudulent purposes.
My dear colleagues, France, like the rest of the European Union, is committed.

Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, it should be noted that our fellow citizens increasingly wish to find and consume locally produced and seasonal food for reasons of health and quality, among other things.
We must find ways to enable farmers to respond effectively and quickly to this growing demand.

We must support the establishment of local infrastructures for producers, such as maintaining nearby slaughterhouses that, while ensuring rigorous health control, allow for the development of local short supply chains and strengthen direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales should help producers to market their products and make them known to consumers.
Strengthening these direct relationships will enable farmers to retain a larger share of the added value created on their farms.

Direct sales on the farm should be encouraged and facilitated, and collective actions by farmers who wish to open collective sales points should be supported, allowing a wider range of products to be offered to local consumers.

The European Commission must facilitate the emergence, sustainability, and development of direct-to-consumer delivery sales systems, such as AMAPs in France, which enable nearly 3 farmers to supply 60 families.

Finally, Member States must be able to add other criteria, particularly concerning the size of the farm, the volume of production, or the traditional nature of the product, in order to define local agriculture.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased that this amending budget concerning the financing of ITER, which has been voted on, received a large majority in the Committee on Budgets on 29 March.
By financing this additional cost, we avoid abandoning a strategic fundamental research project in which the European Union plays a leading role, and we honor our international commitments.
It should be noted that none of the seven partners in the Euratom community have questioned their overall contribution to the project.
Despite the Fukushima disaster, Japan has decided to scrupulously respect its budgetary commitments to ITER.
Without this agreement, hundreds of researchers would have had to suspend their work and the ITER project would have experienced detrimental delays.
Today, a thousand people work for ITER in Kadaraš.
From 2015 to 2017, the construction phase of the buildings and assembly of the machine could employ up to 4 people on this site.
In conclusion, Mr. President, ITER is a source of pride for Europe and a symbol of our excellence.
Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur, thank you for the work we have done together.
The European Union needs a manifesto, a common political vision on the major challenges related to the environment, for the horizon 2020 and beyond.
This is the whole point of launching a seventh environmental action programme by creating synergies between existing financial frameworks and mobilising new funding resources.
This program must ensure consistency and coordination between the European Union's environmental strategies and sectoral policies, whether in agriculture
Fishing, research and innovation, health, transport, regional development, land use planning and urban policies, of course.
Despite the economic crisis that is battering the European Union, we must not succumb to a short-term vision and abandon all ambition in the environmental and climate field.
Inaction would be fatal.
The stakes are too high, especially when it comes to the effective use of our resources and the enhancement of natural capital.
We must therefore resolutely invest in sustainable economy and eco-innovation, which are sources of growth, competitiveness and employment.
It is our responsibility to promote eco-design, recycling, and the environmental labeling of products in order to avoid waste and poor consumption choices.
We cannot overlook this environmental education that is necessary for European citizens.
The environmental action programme is a political programming instrument, but it is also a communication tool.
It must provide the necessary readability and predictability to national and local governments, citizens, as well as entrepreneurs and investors regarding the European Union's environmental choices.
European regulation must not become a punishment or a straitjacket.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of the profound changes that our world is undergoing today, the Union must reform its generalised system of preferences.
Like any compromise, this one does not break the rule.
While it is satisfactory from a strictly commercial point of view, it is far from perfect. We must bear in mind that this regulation is aimed at developing countries.
By developing its new paradigm of differentiation, the Commission says it wants to refocus its efforts on the poorest countries.
This does not seem entirely sustainable at first glance.
To achieve this, the Commission has nevertheless developed a strictly accounting approach based solely on the criterion of GDP per capita.
The limitations of this approach are clear.
Leaving many middle-income developing countries behind, whose economies are undiversified and vulnerable to climate risks.
The compromise reached with the Council does not address this issue, which is why I am calling on my fellow Members to vote in favour of the three amendments that will be tabled on this text.
Commissioner, the problem of the availability of public consultations in the various languages of the European Union is unfortunately not new.
This is a crucial issue, in my opinion, which is why I have already not only asked several written questions to the European Commission since 2008, but I have also personally written to Mr Barroso.

Indeed, the Commission must comply with the principle of equal treatment and access to information for all European citizens, as the Court of First Instance of the European Communities recalled in its judgment of 20 November 2008.
Mr President, I was not at all satisfied with the European Commission's response that public consultations do not claim to provide a fully representative picture of all opinions.
According to this response, the Commission takes into account the fact that certain positions and views may be overrepresented to the detriment of others.
That's not an answer.
I am wondering about the criteria that would allow us to measure an overrepresentation of the European population.
If written consultations are not overrepresented because of English language availability alone, for example, they fail in their goal of consulting European citizens.
Thus, the result gives a misleading indication and should therefore not be used by the European Commission.
If we want to retain written consultations as a tool at the basis of the European Commission's legislative proposals, we must ensure a democratic, transparent and fair system for all citizens.
Thus, if the European Commission conducts written consultations, it must take responsibility and ensure the necessary resources for multilingualism and the translation of questionnaires.
In conclusion, I would like to add that multilingualism is not the only obstacle.

The analysis should also take into account the excessively short deadlines for submitting contributions, as well as the limited resources deployed by the Commission to communicate about these consultations, which are unfortunately mostly accessible only to those in the know. Thank you for your understanding.
The proposed regulations aim to give the European Commission increased powers to control national budgets and economic policies.
The rules will be stricter, and defaulting states will be imposed by the technocrats in Brussels with budget cuts and structural reforms in order to restore their financial balance.
This enhanced monitoring is called guardianship.
States will be punished, fined, spanked, so to speak, financial sanctions will be strengthened and more automatic.
Even if some amendments aim to prevent budget austerity alone by means of growth measures, your proposals are only there to sweeten the pill.
Growth, as you know, like I do, cannot be decreed.
Without consulting the people and with the complicity of Brussels, we are definitively losing our budgetary sovereignty, our freedom to choose our policies.

And when, little by little, according to the tactics of the Chinese thief, the bureaucratic, technocratic, and totalitarian European state has finally been established, we will have lost our freedom as a people altogether.
Mr President, without underestimating the importance of the economic choices we have to face up to, allow me to insist on a point of a more political nature in the context of this debate.
In recent weeks, we have once again seen evidence of the double-speak of certain major European leaders, or those who believe themselves to be such.
While everyone continues to advocate for a coordination of economic, budgetary, and fiscal policies that is finally worthy of the name, and while this requirement even appears to be a condition
an equivalent of the survival of the eurozone, these clever Mr. Crosses, once settled in their homes, decry the balanced recommendations coming from
the Commission to be released from certain commitments or, in the worst case scenario, to turn public opinion against these Brussels bureaucrats, as has been said.
This irresponsible attitude would be laughable if we were not in such a tragic situation.
I'll tell you straight, our debates on stability, the necessary improvement of public finances, or the efforts to be made in terms of growth are indeed doomed to
failure if the past mistakes in terms of debt and public deficit do not come to an end and if the governments of the Member States continue in their misfortune.
We are playing with fire right now.
European discipline must apply to everyone, without exception, including the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg.
This requires a minimum of courage and our public opinion is ready for it, much more so than some of their leaders would like to believe.
