One last word to Mrs Goulard, otherwise I'll have to show her the blue card. I'll say, to conclude, to Mrs Goulard, in Redemption there are redemptions.

Mr President, I would first like to commend the determination of the European Commission and particularly yours, Commissioner, for tirelessly placing the relaunch and deepening of the internal market at the top of the European agenda.

As you pointed out, Commissioner, it has been more than two years now that both the Commission and the European Parliament have been working to identify the missing links in the internal market, to identify the issues and sectors that require more internal market, more internal market for more growth, more competitiveness, more jobs.

The European Council, for its part, also ended up, albeit more belatedly, by signaling the importance it attached to the rapid and effective implementation of the twelve priority proposals for the internal market, the twelve levers for growth.
Rather than constantly trying to invent new growth instruments, we would be better off working with the toolkit we already have.

We therefore take the opportunity of the resolution that will be put to the vote in our assembly tomorrow to send a strong political message to the Member States about the need for greater speed and efficiency in transposing the directives that have already been adopted.
It has adopted greater mobilization and commitment in the newly opened projects. I will mention just one: the strengthening of worker mobility, greater ease of movement, and more fluid circulation.
Commissioner, we will be eagerly awaiting the second stage of the act for the single market that you will present after the summer.
We will demonstrate both political will and the ability to put pressure on the member states.
We experienced the Ombudsman scandal some time ago.
We now have the breast implant scandal, which unfortunately highlights, as you said, Commissioner, the shortcomings in European health safety.
This breast implant scandal, these fourteen years of fraud, 1996-2010, went unpunished.
There are 500 prostheses in use worldwide, 8 implant recalls, and 48 confirmed cases of cancer.
Finally, 3 complaints were filed, a figure that frightens, shocks.

How, despite warnings from the American Food and Drug Administration, Commissioner, and the numerous complaints and convictions for prosthetic failures filed in Great Britain, particularly in France, how could national and European agencies have missed such a scam?
This tragedy immediately prompted us to consider improving the European system for monitoring medical devices, as you explained just now.
We must, Commissioner, build a new system today that can prevent scandal, but it is a new system that needs to be built.
This new legislation is scheduled for the autumn, as you mentioned.
As a co-author of this resolution, I am obviously satisfied with it.
But, Commissioner, you seem to want to take into account a large part of our concerns, as dictated by this resolution.
So why make an unacceptable exception for many of the parliamentarians present here?
Why not want to create a marketing authorization for class 3 medical devices, which are the most at risk?
Commissioner Dalli, can you explain your position to me?
Mr. President, we are currently experiencing a situation where production is increasing by more than 2.5%, while at the same time, manufacturers are lowering prices.
In Italy, Germany, England and throughout Europe, prices are falling.
This means very clearly that prices are linked to the volume of production and that it is necessary to organize the volumes of production and, at the same time, the prices.
At the same time, today, producers are suffering from an increase of more than 44% in the price of plant proteins and 30% in the price of cereals.
Parliament has already voted on the need to ensure that added value is shared between producers and that farmers are not exploited by companies and large-scale distribution.

I am asking the Commission today, but also the Council, to reconsider the undermining of control over production, but at the same time I am saying very clearly that the Member States must clean up their own affairs, because there are countries that have respected the quota rules and others that have not.
This is also what led to these quotas being called into question.
There is therefore a dual responsibility for the Commission and the Member States.
Commissioner, dear colleagues, a single European rail area: what a fine example of European integration policy.
This is a fine policy where European construction is at the heart of the daily concerns of Europeans.

Too often criticized for being at a standstill, Europe is finally, through this directive, showing the way for a major sustainable transport policy and opening up the field for a major rail investment policy for employment.

Mr President, I welcome the main measures taken in the organisation of the rail network, the establishment of national regulators in each Member State, and the creation of a five-year multiannual investment contract, thereby stipulating the funding commitments of

railway infrastructure, but I am also pleased about the introduction of transparency in financial flows between managers and operators within integrated companies. The reminder about non-discriminatory access to certain

services and, finally, I am pleased with the confirmation sought by European parliamentarians of certain guarantees, particularly on a social level, for example the absence of a reference to the minimum service as well as full unbundling between the CNR game and the operator.

But allow me to mention a requirement that is no longer being considered, particularly by the European Commission: the liberalization of the railway sector as the sole strategic goal for the development of a single railway area, and thus decide on a European integrated investment strategy that is favorable to employment in Europe.
So, to conclude, I would like to ask you a question, Commissioner Kallas.
Three days ago, after the European Council meeting on June 28 and 29, after the approval of a €120 billion growth pact to stimulate the European economy.
And in particular through investment in infrastructure. Could you tell us, Commissioner, how much the European rail sector is likely to benefit under this growth pact?
Madam President, we will have a debate on ACTA tomorrow, but I would like to address an issue this evening that is certainly peripheral but extremely important in this context.
These were the words used by Commissioner Mr. De Gucht in the Committee on International Trade on Wednesday, June 20.
If you decide to vote against before the European Court rules, let me tell you that the Commission will nevertheless continue to pursue the current procedure before the Court of Justice.
We have committed ourselves to it.
A negative vote will not halt the proceedings before the Court of Justice.

justice. Not only do these remarks seem to me to be a misunderstanding of the treaties, but above all, and this is what I want to denounce, they demonstrate an unacceptable contempt for the European Parliament, democracy in general, and the citizens we represent.
At a time when European citizens, as a whole,
Mr President, a great deal has been said at this point.
Mr Commissioner, for my part, I would like to thank you most sincerely.
Thanks to your obstinacy, your procedural tricks, you allow us to prove the importance of the European Parliament as a co-legislator.
Thank you, Commissioner, for having pushed hundreds of thousands of citizens to take to the streets and 2 to sign petitions.
They discovered that democracy is at stake here, that the elected European officials are the representatives of the people, their representatives.
Thank you once again to the millions of internet users who followed the debates and votes in committee and who are still following us today.
I salute them; it's a breath of fresh air in our institutions, which are all too often perceived as technocratic.
Mr President, Commissioner, but in a democracy, there is also another principle.
This is the fundamental principle, that of responsibility.
Tomorrow, we will take responsibility, and I would like, tomorrow, to thank you for taking responsibility for your failure, the failure of your working method.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking on behalf of Maurice Ponga, the draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development on Mr Gallagher's report.
It seemed important to me to point out that when a nation wants to sanction a country that practices unsustainable fishing, it must take into account its level of development.

In fact, in the name of the principle of policy coherence with development objectives, it is crucial, in my opinion, that measures adopted in the field of fisheries do not undermine the development plans and strategies implemented by the European Union in these countries.
Mr. Gallagher's draft report takes up this important idea for our Development Committee by stipulating that measures must not be unjustified or even discriminatory.

I therefore call on the European Commission, when adopting such measures, to respect this principle of policy coherence with development objectives and to ensure that the level of development and vulnerability of countries are duly taken into account.
The third reform of the common fisheries policy must not once again be carried out against the interests of fishermen.

No, not all fishermen are these plunderers of the sea, solely responsible for the poor health of fish stocks, as environmental organizations and the European Commission claim, lumping all categories of fishing together.

It goes without saying that fish stocks must be preserved, but our fishermen must also be able to make a living from their activity, and the economic fabric, dynamism, and cultural identity of our coastal regions must be preserved.
Or, the main measures of the European executive are once again aimed at reducing the number of fishermen in order to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I would like to remind you that the French fleet has decreased by more than 50 since 1980.

The Commission proposes, in particular, the introduction of individual transferable quotas, a guarantee of industrialization and concentration in the sector, or a total ban on discards, which professionals consider unrealistic.
This reform project is probably suitable for the industrial fleet, but as it stands, it would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the EPP rapporteur, our colleague Karins, on this difficult report, given the sensitive nature of bilateral negotiations in the field of energy between European countries and third countries.
The agreement reached in trilogue will allow for the rapid implementation of the Commission's draft decision, and for pragmatic reasons, one can only welcome this.
Energy Europe is making progress, certainly not fast enough, but it is making progress.
As a major energy importer, the European Union is structurally dependent on certain supplier countries.

In order to have a more European reflection on our energy strategy, it had become necessary to disseminate information on energy agreements more widely to the European Commission, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity.
The establishment of an information mechanism on intergovernmental agreements will therefore improve transparency in the energy market and thus make it possible to anticipate energy supply problems.
I am pleased that this decision does not create obligations regarding agreements between commercial companies.
In times of crisis and given the stakes in terms of competition and competitiveness, we had a duty to protect the interests of our companies and the rules protecting private contracts.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to thank our two rapporteurs for the work they have done on this issue.

It was necessary because we were starting from a very long way behind: the Commission's initial proposal made no specific mention of the outermost regions directly affected by competition from Latin American countries, and there was no automatic trigger.

under the stabilisation mechanism, there is no possibility for our Assembly to request the initiation of a safeguard investigation, and social and environmental standards are not taken into account as potentially constituting an unfair competitive advantage.
That is why it is extremely important that tomorrow's vote validates the progress made on these points in the Committee on International Trade.
Nevertheless, this is not enough because we know that the trigger thresholds for these two regulations are so high that they make these mechanisms practically inapplicable.
Furthermore, the Commission must provide an additional financial envelope to support the competitiveness of Community banana production.
Keep in mind that many jobs are at stake in these European regions, which already have record unemployment rates.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to start by thanking Charles Goerens for his excellent report.
We all know here that the European Union provides more than half of the world's total official development assistance, and yet, as the MDG deadline approaches in 2015, even though some goals seem
Having achieved these results, we must ask ourselves how we can improve our aid, making it more consistent with our trade policy, our agricultural policy, and our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must be based on specific, measurable commitments with a short- and medium-term timeline.

The economic crisis, climate change, the growing power of emerging countries, and land grabbing are forcing us to define new priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources, and access to healthcare.

Certainly, there is a European consensus, but we must rethink European and international institutional systems in environmental and social matters, drawing inspiration from decision-making bodies such as the WTO, for example.
Finally, and most importantly, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third countries is not just about charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for us.
One need only look at the markets opening up for Europeans in emerging countries like China, Brazil, and India.
2015 will also be an opportunity to better take into account the geostrategic evolution of recent years, as the emerging countries of today were, until recently, developing countries.
As major economic powers, these countries must now also contribute to international aid.
The European Union must be the promoter of responsible development aid at the European and international levels.

The year 2015 will be more than just a deadline; it will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not as mere financial assistance, but as support for responsible development projects, both socially and environmentally.

I therefore join here with my colleagues from the other groups and those from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions in calling for 2015 to be designated the European Year of Development and, above all, of responsible development.
Mr President, the agenda for change proposed by the Commission raises many questions in my opinion, the main one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission wants the selection of countries in which the European Union will invest its development aid to be based, from 2014 onwards, on the mechanical application of the simple criterion of wealth per inhabitant.
As Mrs Ashton pointed out, these issues are not just about accounting, but deserve a genuine political debate on how we define our priorities in terms of international cooperation.
Moreover, in my opinion, this differentiated approach is not in line with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that ACP countries that have achieved positive economic performance should be encouraged in their transition towards more sustainable growth. These countries should not be unduly penalized for having succeeded in ensuring growth through discipline, good governance, and prudent economic policies.
Madam President, Commissioner, let us salute the initiative taken by Jacques Delors twenty years ago, at the very moment when the Berlin Wall was falling.

Despite this, despite all the progress we have seen since the beginning of our debate, it must be acknowledged that the Single Act is now synonymous with injustice, inequality, and economic liberalism.
I would therefore like to hear from you, Mr Barnier, Commissioner, to tell us how we are going to build a fairer Europe together, a facilitating Europe, a protective Europe.

There are a number of avenues, and I would like to hear your thoughts on these avenues, which are at the heart of the economic and social crisis, as we unfortunately know, such as tax harmonization and public services.
protectors, minimum wage in Europe, establishment of enhanced cooperation, job creators, facilitating cross-border cooperation and developing a fair trade policy.
These are the challenges, I believe, that lie ahead of us twenty years later.
I am counting on you, Commissioner, to work together to advance this fine policy of European construction.

Mr President, as a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I have taken a close interest in my colleague Regina Bastos's report on the twenty main concerns of citizens and businesses.
We have discussed this report in connection with our debate on the 20th anniversary of the internal market.
It has already been twenty years since the free movement of goods, people, services, and capital was supposed to be fully implemented within our living, exchange, and internal market space.

I was particularly interested in the fact that, at the forefront of the concerns expressed by our European fellow citizens, is the essence of professional qualifications and that we really need to be particularly proactive and particularly effective.

This is what our fellow citizens expect in order to truly be able to implement, in the very near future, procedures for recognizing their diplomas, skills, and professional qualifications that are truly faster, simpler, more efficient, and less costly.
It is a real challenge.

As the shadow rapporteur for the EPP group on this subject, the modernisation of these procedures, I am actively working with the other members of the IMCO committee to truly meet this major mobility challenge.
For more mobility, for more Europe, that is what our fellow citizens are asking for. Thank you.
Mr President, this year the Committee on Petitions acquired the right to be automatically associated with the hearing of European citizens' initiatives.
For me, this is the most significant signal of 2011 for this Commission.
Citizens already had a Commission to turn to in case of non-respect of their rights, but this is now also the case when they have proposals to improve European legislation.
I hope that the Committee on Petitions can thus be increasingly seen as the preferred interlocutor for citizens in the European Parliament.
This issue of consideration is also reflected in the results of the Committee on Petitions' positions.
All too often, we are approached by citizens who are facing legal complications on which we wish to take a stand, but when the problems are European,
Even though the solutions should be European, we remain powerless because subsidiarity is still not compatible with European solutions due to a lack of national will.

Mr President, I will take the difficult example of transnational divorces. The problems are both national and European when custody or visitation rights cross national borders, in this case those of Germany.
Despite the glaring difficulties faced by many parents with children born of binational unions, we in Parliament remain powerless to act.

My proposal for all European citizens to have the right to a national ombudsman, especially from Germany, which sends a large number of petitions following the model of the Defender of Rights in France, has not been implemented.
However, in the case of transnational divorces, it remains a conciliatory solution, a European problem, and a national solution.
In many cases, European law seems powerless to meet citizens' expectations.
The 2013 European Year of Citizens will have to address citizens' grievances and costs, but we need the means to act in order to be effective.
